name: Saints Row IV
description: The US President must save the Earth from alien overlord Zinyak using an arsenal of superpowers and strange weapons in the wildest open world game ever.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista (x86 or x64) Processor: Intel Core 2 Quad Q6600 | AMD Athlon II x3 Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GTX 260 | AMD Radeon HD 5800 series DirectX: Version 10 Storage: 10 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 (x86 or x64) Processor: Intel i3 2100T | AMD Phenom II x4 or higher Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GTX 560 | AMD Radeon HD 6800 series or higher DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 10 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Saint's Row IV
As a Saints Row game, I can't stand this game.  As a game in general, it's a lot of fun

Saints Row IV is an open world single-player/co-op game with a story where you're free do whatever you want in a huge city. Now, that doesn't sound original since GTA and previous Saints Row games have already done it before, but Saints Row IV is the first of them to let you use all kinds of awesome super powers on enemies and civilians in the cities!
You can create a minigun-wielding super-powered toilet with a Cockney accent.  10/10

Smug-faced, stylish, hilarious and a bit heavy for logical processing. Lots of easter eggs, too. And sometimes buggy, too. Nothing like GTA-clone it was back in the day.  Careful: vast amount of obscene themes. If you're a purist or a 'normal' person, don't hurt yourself.
An exact replica of my life.
this game made my balls wet
This game gave me a boner
You can't know if its a bug/glitch or made on purpose:D

This is a great game. You can blow s**t up with your hands, run insanely fast, and cause so much havoc. The story is awesome, the combat is really fun, and there is so much customization in this game.  Pros: - Lots of little gamemodes to play, and the story is fun. - Loads of insane weapons to use, from assault rifles to black hole guns. - Lots of customization - Just about every part of the game can be done in Co-op - So many awesome super powers!  Cons: - Random crashes when using high graphical settings and sometimes in Co-op - FPS can be low in cutscenes  The communication in multiplayer could be a bit better. When you want to speak to someone through text chat, it links you through to chat with them on the steam chat. Often it says the person is offline, even though you are playing with them. And if you go on their profile, it says they are playing Saints Row IV. The only way you can really talk to people through text is to either talk in the comments section on their profile (which isn't a good idea) or send them a friend request, but that's if they actually accept it. You can only really use mic to talk, which I don't tend to use.  But nevertheless,  in my honest opinion, I give it a 9/10 :D

After absolutely loathing SR3, I played SR4 to get it off my backlog. Boy, am I glad I did.  SR4 is, at least in my opinion, superior to 3 in every aspect. The combat is a lot more fun, upgrades actually mean something, side activities are addictive, you actually LAUGH at the story, and collectibles and challenges seem like fun side quests instead of boring filler. I completed the story and 100 percent of the open world/side quests, and I loved it. Coming from someone who hated SR3, SR4 is definitely worth your time.
Ridiculously hilarious but not immaturely childish.  Unimaginably super-powered but not illogically impractical.

Surprisingly disappointing when compared to the comic genius of SR2 and SR3. The jokes / gags just weren't on par, and while some of the classic scenes were drug out yet again for a quick laugh it still just wasn't where I expected the sequel to be. The super powers were all basically ripped straight from Prototype, in which they were all implimented much better. Get it for a sale and you'll have a good time with it, but as a huge fan of the Saints Row franchise I felt like this one was rushed out, repetitive, and had all the hallmarks of a studio cash grab. Shockingly average would be the best description.

-Quick Review-   Saints Row IV is an Open World Action world, which a delightful mix of humor and drama, the game starts out playing as a third person shooter, and then switches over to feeling like you're playing a super hero game. I've actually been putting off writing this review because I've been having so much fun playing through the game a second time. That should speak volumes for itself.   -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:  'Greetings Mr./Ms. President your immediate attention is needed regarding the problems of ruling the entire United Sates.' *Zap zap zap*' *Gasp*  who are you?'  We are the Zin and we come in peace.  'Really? you just killed three of our secret agents and ruined the press conference'   psych!  *pew pew pew* I don't want to give anything away specific about the story, simply put your crew has been abducted by aliens and it's your job to save them and bring down Zinyak to save the human race. The story is full of humor, I found myself laughing aloud at the countless references and the ways these characters interacted with each other.   Game Play:  As you play through the game you unlock various 'super powers', from sprinting, to running, to firing ice, telekinesis, or ground stomp. The super powers flow seamlessly with the story, and genuinely make game play pleasurable to experience. In addition to super powers, you also have various weapons that you can use, my personal favorite was the energy-sword (of course), but you had guns, hand to hand combat, laser guns, regular guns, rocket launchers, and many alien weapons that get unlocked as you play through the game.    Achievements:  The achievements on this game are broken down into four categories: 1) Main story achievements. 2) doing all the things, and probably missed the first time through achievements. 3) DLC achievements.  4) Broken achievement  1) As the title implies most of the main story achievements you get just by playing through, you will get close to 10-15 achievements just playing through. 2) The achievements I ended up missing were a few grinding achievements that I could do at the end of the game, in addition to doing the side missions AFTER the last boss... so I need to play through the whole game again. (normally this would be immensely annoying for me, but this game is definitely fun a second time through) 3) You need to buy the DLC, and I don't own it at the moment.   4) I'm highlighting this because if you want to get 100% for this game, it is impossible at this time (2/6/2015) because one achievement requires you to connect to  saintsrow.com , and there was a recent shut down for the provider of that service, so you can no longer upload a character from in the game (or log on within the Saints Row IV Client, for that matter).  I was able to successful log into my saints row account and upload a character on 09/27/15.    Price:  The standalone version without any DLC is priced at $19.99, that is a fair price based on the amount of time I've personally put into the game, and this is a game that can be replayed and enjoyed again, If you already know you like the saints row series, you should probably go for a Game of the Century Edition, or Ultimate Franchise Pack.  As always, waiting for a sale is most beneficial to your pocket book, but this game is totally worth every dollar.     Conclusion:  This game is going on my top list for favorite games I've played, I've also learned how to identify some qualities in games that I tend to really enjoy playing, from playing Saints Row IV. To quickly recap, The story was hilarious, and entertaining, the game play was excellent, The achievements were great except for the broken achievement, the price is fair. This game appeals to most people, but especially people who enjoy open world games. I should add one comment regarding tech requirements, the game came out in 2013, so it was rough on my personal computer, I tried troubleshooting, but in the end just kept playing, even though the game crashed occasionally. ----Still love the game.  ------Edits and updates------ Edit/Update January 10, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for  Saints Row IV: How the Saints Save Christmas  Edit/Update February 26, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for  Saints Row IV - Enter The Dominatrix  Edit/Update April 17, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for  Saints Row: The Third   Edit/Update September 27, 2015: Broken achievement fixed.
One of the most awesome kickass crazy games i played! Its a must if you love FUN!

Masterpiece from Saints Row series again! Extremely creative, ridiculous, hilarious and funny game ever. Being an U.S. president fight against alien invasion with your homie. Get inside the virtual Steelport, use various special weapons and your super power to defeat the alien. Yeah, kinda like the concept in movie The Matrix. And feel like Prototype the game. Really love it! Besides, several characters, scenes, stories in previous Saints Row titles are showing up in Saints Row IV. It's so good to see those old memories coming alive again in the new game world. :D  黑街聖徒又一個巨作！是一款極度創意、惡搞、娛樂又有趣的遊戲，身為美國總統和你的弟兄們一起阻止外星人入侵，進入虛擬城市Steelport，使用豐富又特別的武器和超能力打敗外星人，沒錯，這部份有很多都很像電影駭客任務的概念那樣，玩起來感覺也很像原型兵器，真的很喜歡！ 此外，許多黑街聖徒前作的角色、場景、故事都再次出現在四代中，看到這些以往回憶再次在新的遊戲中重新呈現，實在很棒 :D

Coming to Saints Row from GTA I did not take the game franchise seriously. However I started with the second game and was amazed at an actual fantastic story about gang violence and the ups and downs of the crime life. It was fantastic with great fun gameplay and exciting mission variety. The third was a turn in the direction of nonsensical sillyness. The fourth continues on this trend much to some chagrines, I personally think its refreshing. I love a game that knows its not taking itself seriously and is just meant to be fun and over the top. The funny thing is this is the best 'super power' game out there. This game is fantastic and even better with the fully drop in drop out coop with a friend. You can play every second of this game all the missions everything with a friend. Its a fantastic coop experiance. If you and your friend like screwing around in a virtual world THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU! This game is pure rediculous fun. Its a game where the devs did not forget to make their game fun. So if you like fun, buy this game. 9/10 AMAZING COOP

Disclaimer: I binged through this game in about 5 days' time because of sleeping troubles. Some of the following may not apply if you play this at a sane rate.  A huge amount of how you feel about SR4 is probably going to relate to how you felt about SR3, because not-really-a-spoiler: your open world is 99% Steelport again. (There are minor changes.) Even being given extra time after the implosion of former publisher THQ, this game was clearly originally an expansion, and some parts of it really show that corner-cutting when you play through it. On the plus side, though - some of the reuse is done in actual clever ways, and this is where I come to my huge divide about the game: the gameplay gets really, really tired at times, but the writing is pretty sharp.  This game was a pretty clear sendoff/love letter to the franchise, going as far back as SR1 and a whole lot of nods to the earlier titles the further you go along. In fact, probably the entire back half of the game* is winking fanservice to SR1/2 and the stuff that 3 dropped a lot of. Let me point out: none of it is what I'd call 'half-♥♥♥♥♥', either. They seriously got the original VAs from these games to replay their roles, made entire mini-arcs for them, and added optional content to the point of letting you recruit some deep cut characters. Or, if you buy the 'complete' edition with DLCs - just plain cut characters.  I could go on and make a huge list of the ups and downs of this, but basically, do you want to run around a virtual world as a superpowered god, causing mayhem and comedy in your wake? That's this game. It's a superpowered ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ simulator and it doesn't pretend to be anything else.  I will give one handy tip, though: upgrade the alien weapons, no matter whether you like them or not. You're going to be stuck with them on more than one mission. Don't get shafted like I was and enter some of the late-game stuff with level 0 guns doing piddly damage.  (Side-note: if you're like me and really dig sites like The Cutting Room Floor and exploration of dummied-out/cut/scrapped content from games, you really owe it to yourself to buy the Enter the Dominatrix DLC, which is basically an extended look at what the original scope of this game was going to be when it was just an SR3 expansion, complete with commentary.)  * Note: back half of the game also consists of a lot of stellar burns on Mass Effect.

After playing Saints Row IV for just over fifteen hours, beating the campaign, and enjoying a few side missions along the way, I have noticed vast improvements throughout the series.  Customization:  As most of you should know, customization is key in games such as Saints Row, Grand Theft Auto, and other sandbox games along these lines. Games in the Saints Row franchise have all had some sort of deep customization. Players can create exact replicas of themselves, or even turn into whatever they desire. Although in this addition to the series, we are not left disappointed. The possibilities are endless. Would you like to go around shooting people with Dual Wielded SMGs? You can do that! Want to shoot up a store with Han Solo's signature blaster? You can do that too! Whatever you sick little mind can come up with; you can do it.  Gameplay: Looking back at Saints Row: The Third, you'll definitely notice how many of the activities have reappeared. Some of your favorites such as Tank Mayhem and Insurance Fraud. Although, in this addition to the franchise, the activities have gotten far more challenging; giving the player a harder time and not making the game drift away so quickly. For example, when you're ragdolling your character around the city in Insurance Fraud, you'll need to gain a certain amount of money to either earn Bronze, Silver, or Gold!  City Upgrades: If you've played any of the other Saints Row games, you've probably noticed the lack of aerial combat. That has changed completely in Saints Row IV. When the developers added the VTOL hover-jets and rocket cycles, it just makes the game feel that much more entertaining. We've also seen improvements on the vertical areas of Stilwater, it's far easier to throw yourself off the top of a building to a quick and easy death. That is, only if you don't have your superpowers activated ;)  Removal of Importance: Remember in the previous Saints Row games when you had to earn 'respect' from your crew and gang? They've removed that and simply changed it's name to XP. While this makes sense due to the scenerios and there only being about nine humans technically alive. It still makes the game feel a little less like the classic 'Saints Row' style game.  Cars and Music: Basically since this game takes place almost entirely inside a computer simulation, you can do some pretty awesome things. One of them being that you can hijack a car and then 'upload' it into your virtual garage. Later on, you can simply 'download' it to wherever you may be on the map. It's pretty much the same as the cars, but now you can play music wherever you may be. Yes, you read that correctly. You don't even need to be in a car! This adds a whole new level of excitement to the game, and makes it much more enjoyable.  Overall: Overall, this game was fun to play through and gave me plenty of time driving around and killing ferocious aliens. Although it kind of seems like a let down, it feels just like a large expansion to Saints Row: The Third. It's the end of 2016 and I still recommend it, as it has a unique story and will give you many laughs along the way!

A focus on super powers puts this game in a different space than the GTA influences of the past, making this fresh and fun.  Some of the best parody in big budget games to boot. .

Field     Rating     Comments         Graphics    8.0   Graphically, this isn't all that much of a step up from the last entry. While they aren't bad by any stretch of the imagination, they leave a little bit to be desired considering it's the same engine, same city, and mostly the same characters and vehicles.        Soundtrack    7.5   The music on the radio stations, while not bad, leaves a lot to be desired. After the amazing soundtracks of Saints Row: The Third and Saints Row 2, I feel as if we should have expected more from this one. All-in-all though, still a pretty good, not so bad soundtrack.        Sound Effects    8.5   The sound effects throughout the game range from disappointing to absolutely perfect. A lot of the lower tier weapons (mostly the ones you are more likely to find in the real world) lack any kind of real umph, making them feel weaker than I feel they were intended to be. The more creative weapons, however, generally get me excited at the very thought of pulling them out. There is no joy like unleashing the power of the Dubstep Cannon.        Story    9.0   As Saints Row has shown with its previous installment, it pulls no punches as far as going as ridiculous as they can possibly go. As the newly elected President, it is your job to save the world from an oncoming alien invasion, getting abducted and sent into a Matrix-like simulation of the city from the third game. The main difference is that, since it is no longer grounded by the rules of reality, you can now develop superpowers as you progress through the game's story and side missions. While remaining silly and over the top throughout, Saints Row IV still manages to keep you attached to the characters, keeping small quirks and emotional moments right where they need to be. The only major complaint that I had with this story is   when you do reach the end of the game, the ending boss fight leaves a lot to be desired, and the bad guy is not in the game nearly as much as he should be.          Overall     8.25    While I'll admit I was a little bit disappointed to see that this game took place in the same city as the last game, the new abilities really gave the game a face lift for me. It still packs the hilarious punch of the last game and provides you with something all together new to do. If you're looking for a game like Grand Theft Auto or the first three Saints Row games, honestly, I'd keep looking, but if you are a fan of the series and don't mind a more Prototype-like experience, I would highly recommend this one.  You can skip on most of the DLC though, it's mostly pretty disappointing.

Being the fourth in the series, Saints Row 4 has a rich backstory and large cast of characters that are constantly referenced throughout the game. I only played parts 3 and 4, so I recognized about 3/4 of the characters in the game. For those unfamiliar, the Saints Row franchise seems to be a parody of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, but I can’t say for sure, since I haven’t played any of the GTA games.   Short recap of Saints Row the Third (the previous game): The Third Street Saints (a street gang) have become world famous pop culture icons despite being a bunch of criminals. They have their own TV shows, sports drink, and people want to grow up to be like them. Unfortunately, a large and powerful crime Syndicate has come to town to destroy the Saints and take over the city. And that’s not all. The US Military (or some kind of military unit) has been dispatched to deal with the Saints as well, with access to some very high tech equipment.  In Saints Row 4, after saving the world from the villains in SR3, the Boss of the Saints (you) has been elected President of the United States. Things are going great up until an alien invasion devastates the planet and kidnaps a bunch of humans to be locked in a computer simulation (basically the Matrix). You discover that by causing mayhem and absorbing “code” in the simulation, you can acquire super powers such as super running speed, super jumping , and later on, energy blasts/telekinesis/super stomps. These abilities, mixed with an arsenal of weapons (human and alien) can be used to trash the game world and try to bring the whole system down. Most of Saints Row 4 takes place in the computer simulation, but there are segments where you’re in the “real world” as well. In the real world you can interact with rescued team members (with a romance system) and pilot an alien space ship around.  Like its predecessors, Saints Row 4 is a third person shooter with a large city you can walk, drive, or fly through. Weapons are bought and upgraded in gun shops found all over the city along with clothing stores (for character customization) and car shops. The city is filled with various activities and missions that you can start by just walking up and pressing a key. These include Mayhem (Blow up as much as you can with the weapons given to you in a time limit), Racing, and Insurance Fraud (you ragdoll around being hit by cars to rack up a huge medical bill). With the addition of super powers, there’s a lot more variety than in the previous games, but it really makes cars and even planes obsolete since you can run/super jump faster than any vehicle.   There are also a large number of collectibles in the game such as data clusters (used to upgrade your powers) and Audio Logs, which are short recorded messages giving you backstory. I thought it would be impossible to collect them all for the Steam achievement but on my second playthrough it looks like I might actually do it. This is because your game map is much more detailed than I realized, and after a particular upgrade, you will be able to see all the collectibles on your map (kind of like the Batman Arkham games but without puzzles blocking you). By the way I should probably note that the achievements in SR4 are for a single playthrough. You can’t play through the game 10 times and think everything will add up to the achievement goal. For example you actually have to kill 1000 aliens with your superpowers in one playthrough. This means grinding is necessary on a few of the achievements.  Pros: +A lot of humor in the game with its over the top story and characters. The game is definitely a parody with silly names and crazy missions. +A lot of variety in gameplay. There’s everything from side scrolling 2-D fighting, to tank/mech battles, to fighting Godzilla size monsters. Remember that the game world is a computer simulation so they can do just about anything they want. +The story is decent and the game is pretty long so you should get your money’s worth. It also has a co-op mode which I haven’t tried. It seems to be its own save file though, independent of your single player campaign.  Cons: -You’ll notice that there is a lot of repetition in the game despite the variety of activities you can take part in. Most of the side quests are the same (Do a series of mini-games). You can bypass them of course, but you’d miss out on unlocking upgrades to your superpowers. -Some of the Steam achievements seem like they would take forever to complete such as “complete ALL challenges” (challenges are like in game achievements). No doubt I could do them eventually, but it would take an extra 50 hours of gameplay. And remember it needs to be in a single playthrough. Also, a bunch of achievements are for the game’s DLCs which I don’t own.  Overall, the game is worth playing if you can get your hands on it. Steam had a free weekend a while back and I know a couple people who finished the game during the 3 days. The price hasn’t quite dropped to “bargain bin” level though it’s on sale occasionally. I’ve heard some people say the game is like a DLC for Saints Row the Third, and I can see what they mean. The graphics are nearly identical (as far as I can remember) and both have the same gameplay feel (except with super powers). If you liked Grand Theft Auto / Sleeping Dogs type games but wished you weren’t restrained by the limitations of reality, give Saints Row 4 a try.

The city is filled with various activities and missions that you can start by just walking up and pressing a key. These include Mayhem (Blow up as much as you can with the weapons given to you in a time limit), Racing, and Insurance Fraud (you ragdoll around being hit by cars to rack up a huge medical bill). With the addition of super powers, there’s a lot more variety than in the previous games, but it really makes cars and even planes obsolete since you can run/super jump faster than any vehicle.   There are also a large number of collectibles in the game such as data clusters (used to upgrade your powers) and Audio Logs, which are short recorded messages giving you backstory. I thought it would be impossible to collect them all for the Steam achievement but on my second playthrough it looks like I might actually do it. This is because your game map is much more detailed than I realized, and after a particular upgrade, you will be able to see all the collectibles on your map (kind of like the Batman Arkham games but without puzzles blocking you). By the way I should probably note that the achievements in SR4 are for a single playthrough. You can’t play through the game 10 times and think everything will add up to the achievement goal. For example you actually have to kill 1000 aliens with your superpowers in one playthrough. This means grinding is necessary on a few of the achievements.  Pros: +A lot of humor in the game with its over the top story and characters. The game is definitely a parody with silly names and crazy missions. +A lot of variety in gameplay. There’s everything from side scrolling 2-D fighting, to tank/mech battles, to fighting Godzilla size monsters. Remember that the game world is a computer simulation so they can do just about anything they want. +The story is decent and the game is pretty long so you should get your money’s worth. It also has a co-op mode which I haven’t tried. It seems to be its own save file though, independent of your single player campaign.  Cons: -You’ll notice that there is a lot of repetition in the game despite the variety of activities you can take part in. Most of the side quests are the same (Do a series of mini-games). You can bypass them of course, but you’d miss out on unlocking upgrades to your superpowers. -Some of the Steam achievements seem like they would take forever to complete such as “complete ALL challenges” (challenges are like in game achievements). No doubt I could do them eventually, but it would take an extra 50 hours of gameplay. And remember it needs to be in a single playthrough. Also, a bunch of achievements are for the game’s DLCs which I don’t own.  Overall, the game is worth playing if you can get your hands on it. Steam had a free weekend a while back and I know a couple people who finished the game during the 3 days. The price hasn’t quite dropped to “bargain bin” level though it’s on sale occasionally. I’ve heard some people say the game is like a DLC for Saints Row the Third, and I can see what they mean. The graphics are nearly identical (as far as I can remember) and both have the same gameplay feel (except with super powers). If you liked Grand Theft Auto / Sleeping Dogs type games but wished you weren’t restrained by the limitations of reality, give Saints Row 4 a try.

How much videogame is too much videogame? THat's the question Volition clearly set out to answer and I think we arrived at 'dunno, can we cram a bit more videogame in there, there's a bit of space left just over there'.   Within the first half hour you're ridiculously overpowered with super powers, by the end of the game, you're even more ridiculously overpowered with super powers and armed with a jump that can set off a nuclear explosion. No, really. Honest. You are.  Or at least, it would have been within the first half hour if I hadn't spent the first four hours playing the tutorial just because moving around the not-City is so enjoyable.   As no-one ever had the sense to bring Crackdown to the PC (IDIOTS), this is about the closest you can get. It is, and doesn't pretend not to be for a second, Crackdown does Saints Row:As Redefined In Saints Row III. Which is JUST FINE.

I personally hated this game. I came into it with only positive expectations and was severely let down. I mourn the loss of the 4 dollars that went into buying this garbage.  Let's start with the comedy, which many people say is one of this game's strongsuits. This game has very 'adult' comedy, but it ironically comes off as very childish. It's like some 7th grader talking about how much he loves weed and drugs, and making dumb ♥♥♥♥ jokes to his equally dumb friends. The references to other video game series are only references, and don't really hold any comedic weight. The funniest parts in this game are when characters are conversing, without any dumb gimmick. The witty dialouge is so much more enjoyable than 'Do a Barrel Roll XD' or '♥♥♥♥♥ XD'.  The story isn't much better, however, I don't think anybody actually cares about the story. I wouldn't either, if it didn't hinder the game to the extent that it does. The entire game takes place inside of a simulation, which makes it feel like nothing you do has any weight. Who cares if you die? Who cares about the people you're killing? It's only a simulation. All game I was begging to be taken out the simulation, and put in an actually appealing environment. The story is essentially just you doing a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t withh the excuse of that it's 'weakening the simulation'.  The gameplay was simply aggravating. I remmber being stunlocked to death many times, especially by the people with bats. This is not challenging gameplay, this is annoying gameplay. The boss fights usually turn into a game of 'Find the exploit' Since fighting them is so boring. Shooting feels incredibly dull too, it's as if I'm shooting a paintball gun. The powers are by far the best part of this game, but it gets extremely annoying when I have to switch to one of my boring powers in order to deal with people who are stunlocking me. The powers also lose their excitement as the game wears on though.

I can't think of a better game I've played this year, sometimes the game seems nonsensical but it laughs at itself for it, throughout the entire thing this game is for fun, everything about it is just fun.  It steals ideas from other games and films but who cares? The story is excellent, over the top and hilarious fun to play with a friend, if you can port your character from SR3 too using the website then you can continue the story of your character.  Negatives : + Shame they lost the hispanic voice, but the french one is decent enough. + Multiplayer occasionally broke, reconnecting normally fixed it, just one nearly game breaking issue near the end where one of us had to wait at the start of the map for the other to finish a section.  I can't remember if I've played a better game this year, but I do know this is the most fun I've had on a game for ages.

In this game, you play as Steve Oldboy (or Stephana if you choose female gender) Trapped in a mind vortex between the apalachian mountains on a trip from france, you find yourself in a strange new place where there are bad guys trying to kill you, and you only want one thing: Revenge. The story is beautifully integrated into the gameplay where you never know if you are stuck in the vortex-coma space or real time. You think you wake up, but waking up was just a dream within the coma (you may find this as hard to follow as inception at times) so you go forth to take your revenge while time is slowing down as it runs out, your 'homeboys' backing you up cheering at you to destroy the big bad guy (of which there are several) Then once you think you can wake up you start walking the streets blasting your brain powers over all the bad people when you realize that you brain powers shouldn't be real, or should they? There is a twist.  Overall a good game if you keep a notepad and jot down some notes to follow the story.

'Mr Anderson, welcome back'  The latest game in the Saints Row series has gone through a lot before we got to play it ourselves. Originally intended as a DLC for Saints Row: The Third, it was expanded far beyond that, and then the original Publishers for the series, THQ, went bust and this was picked up by Deep Silver. This could have been a very different game, but rather than consider what might have been, I'm here to let you know what we did get. So on to the review.   Story The game opens up with a mission where you and your crew need to stop an old enemy from attacking the US with nuclear weapons. Once you have obviously succeeded at this, you then spend several years as the President of the United States before Earth is attacked by aliens. After failing to fight back, you find yourself in the Matrix, and must learn to use this to your advantage so you can stop the alien leader and save the planet. That is all in the first hour, and only gets even crazier as you get further in the game. Its just a little over the top, but they had to outdo the previous game somehow. Saints Row has become all about having a crazy story, and Volition didn't want to disappoint.  Presentation In these aspects, the game has changed little from the previous release. Everything still looks pretty much the same, other than a few effects showing off the fact that you spend most of the game in a simulation, such as pixelization of surroundings, and the occasional glitched character (don't worry, they are meant to be messed up). The voice acting is just as good as the previous game as well, with the characters sounding as they did the last time you spent taking on enemies of the Row. Sound effects don't appear to have changed either. All of it makes it obvious that while it might have gone far beyond the original plans, this was going to be a DLC for an older game.  Now, the soundtrack at least has seen some additions, but also the loss of some older stations. The metal of The Blood is no more along with the loss of WDDT and Kabron. It instead has Mad Decent for your rap needs and Four 20 with a mix of reggae and dub. Fortunately, if you share my taste in music and listen to The Mix, you will still be satisfied by the quality of the music even if we can't sing The Final Countdown. Looking at the full selection of songs, it might not be as good as it was in Saints Row 2, but the playlist available in this game is still impressive. A nice little feature they also included is the ability to play music outside of a vehicle. Very happy with that, as you may not spend much time putting up with wheels.   Controls Another place where there have been few changes, the controls have gotten away with only a few minor tweaks to take into account the powers you have access to. Grenades have been removed so they had somewhere to map the powers, and taunts as well as recruiting and dismissing gang members now require you to hold as those keys are also used to toggle your powers. Everything else still works as it did in Saints Row: The Third.   Gameplay Now, here is where all the changes will be found. To start with, it plays just like Saints Row: The Third. Get a car, drive around, etc. But early in the game,you start picking up data clusters and taking down the Wardens of the simulation, allowing you to unlock special abilities. Running around as fast as a car and jumping like Spider-Man, then later then gliding around as if you were that guy in Prototype. Suddenly, you have little reason to even bother with a car. Not only can you cover more ground outside of one, you won't find most of the clusters needed to upgrade your powers without hopping around the rooftops to collect them. This very quickly makes most vehicles a waste of time outside of missions and moving around your useless homies.   Wait, did I just call your homies useless? Why, yes, I did. Sadly, when you move around like a demented grasshopper and can shoot fireballs or make earthquakes, some guy with a pistol won't cut it, and they can't even follow you most of the time. I hate it, but you just won't call them up for help, but only because an achievement will unlock after spending enough time with a few of them. Some of the more important homies will eventually gain their own powers by doing certain side missions, but even they are rarely needed on your various quests.   While the changes to the game have made both vehicles and your gang unneeded, the missions themselves continue to be highly enjoyable. From flying through the sky as you chase your current target to giving the smackdown to brutish aliens, the most important part of the game does the job and keeps you busy until you reach the end of the game. You have a significant number of main missions to work on, as well as all the side missions to unlock enhanced homies, extra powers, new weapons and even a new costume or two. Getting everything out of the way will take many hours of fun.   Lifespan Even after completing the main story, there is still enough to do to keep you busy for a while after the credits roll. Each of the takeover activities now has different ranks, allowing you to try for a Gold on each of them. As well as that, you can also work of completing the Challenges, but running around, jumping as much as you can, and wiping out hundreds of aliens in as many ways as possible. And even after you have done all of these and gotten a 100% save, you have the option of doing it all with a friend.   As you can see, this game is great, though not without a few flaws. Still, it is easily worth a purchase. I can't deny it was money well spent.   8 / 10

So, Saints Row IV.  This game is basically what happens if you take the formula of GTA IV and inject it with meta-humour and general self-awareness, then you give it a plot that's 50% Independence Day and 50% The Matrix. It's a crazy fun romp of superpowered action (which is actually played in a game... well, a simulation within the game) where you smash like the Hulk, fly faster than a bullet and jump higher than a skyscraper like Superman, and quip like Deadpool all the time. There is a whole city as an open world, with many activities to carry out (think of them as mini-games, basically), items to find, and of course a main quest which involves you, your friends, and those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ aliens that conquered Earth. Really, man, f**k those aliens.  So is it actually good? Well, it is. But if it has a problem is that the main quest + Loyalty missions (which are side quests but all different and fun like the main ones) don't take much long to complete. And as for everything else... well, after a few hours of play, you're going to be so superpowered that the world around you will be like the literal 'world of cardboard' Superman complained about. It's not hard at all to kill enemies, it in fact is so easy to hurt someone you probably will do it without realizing and end up with half the police of the city running after you. This takes a bit out of the challenge - it's at this point more or less that I just decided to finish the main quest in one go and get over with it. The game is fun and there definitely are some seriously hilarious bits of dialogue and situations, but it's also quite easy. There's nothing pushing me to seek 100% completion, personally. But as it stands, it was a good fun time, and maybe one day or another I'll pick it up to just replay it with a different character and see whether that changes something.  Also: you can romance all your crewmates, no matter your and their sex. That MUST be a good thing.

Saints Row IV or 4 does not fail to impress me! I can do absolutely anything I want in the game-... From jumping across the islands or by running into cars and turning them into flames - causing them to explode. The music in-game is fantastic! The atmosphere as soon as you start is fabulous and the overall combat system is exactly how I remember the Saints Row series being like!  - The guns are unique, alongside the general customerization that is possible! Loads of colours, shapes of guns, even different models of sizes and types for a specific gun slot! It's overall fantastic! - The vehicles are generic, however the customerization again is excellant, being able to add body mods / colours / nos / a page of 50+ rims / it's grand! - The plastic surgery part of the game which allows you to change; gender, race, facial features, bodily features, hair, skin, you name it! ^ I love being able to swap and change, going from a pink haired gym obsessive 6ft black guy, to a 5 ft round black guy with anime green hair and a beard! You name it, the possibilities are vast! - The choice of doing main missions or side missions is grand! Without the main missions you can spend hours running around doing as you please! - So far I have 15 or so hours in Saints Row IV yet I have done around 10 main missions and the rest have been just from side quests and shooting bad guys!   I love the 80s music on certain radio stations and I also love the ability to add your own custom music <- however you'll need to follow a guide online and it takes ages!  Other than that, the only downfall... Saints Row IV offers a great experience to existing or new fans...  Being able to choose colourful clothes, or guns or cars... To people running around with giant monkey or cat masks... To men in gimp costumes... To energy drink cans shooting you with machine guns -... Toilets with guns... Spongey limbs and even having the same NPC spawned 20 times over with some deformity... It all adds into an amazing, unexpected, funny game, full of colour and diverse choice. I totally recommend it!  PS: I have taken a number of screenshots on Saints Row IV - 80 + to be precise, so go through them and definitely get the game :D!!!!

Easily one of the best games I've played yet. I haven't played previous Saint's Row games yet, but they are high on my playlist now.   This game is outrageous. It's funny. It's over-the-top. It's essentially fight aliens inside the Matrix. It's pure fun.   You are loaded with superpowers that increase over time. You can leap tall buildings in a single bound, or run up the walls, or sprint around town far faster than any car can travel. I only used cars when the mission required it. You can shoot blasts of ice or fire from your hands. You can throw people into black holes with a gun, scoop them up and fire them from a cannon with a vehicle, or use telekinesis to drop a truck on them or throw them across town. The upgrade paths are fun, always improving your abilities. The melee animations (for no weapons) are bloody and funny.   There is plenty of diversity in missions and side quests, as you take over the simulated world store by store, block by block. There is puzzle-based hacking similar to Bioshock. There are 'Flashpoints' where you kill all the enemies. You ascend towers by leaping from one platform to the next. You duke it out in the Super Powers arena. You run a time-limited race around town with super speed, then walk around in a mech suit blowing up everything in your path, and wrap things up by slamming your face into buildings, cars, and people to rack up points. You take on 8-bit adventures, fight zombies, and hunt for countless collectibles (Zinyak statues, data points to use as upgrade points, text adventure pieces, audio logs, etc). There's just so much to do and it's all 100% chaos.  The main story is really entertaining and funny. It's a game that never takes itself seriously, but still tells a serious story that brings these characters together against the evil aliens. At a point, all the side quests and collectibles became awfully repetitive, but I still felt driven to plow through them to reach my newest super power. The story missions are varied and enjoyable and the plot reaches a satisfying and epic conclusion.   The game is open world with great graphics. You can walk the streets among countless pedestrians, listening to little sound bytes. You'll see streets full of ordinary citizens and in the middle of it all: a dominatrix walks among the suits and ties. Or a person in hot dog costume. It's strange and that's part of its charm.   I still have to play through any DLC for the game. I did buy the Season Pass, so I will play the additional content in the near future.

This one just adds a little bit more to the mix, aliens, superpowers, and more. I'll just call it SR3 Plus Edition, in that case, if it's on sale, buy it! The Saint's are back and they're as crazy as ever!

Game: Saints Row IV Summary: Crazy fun ridiculousness, with many side missions that feel more like tacked-on mini-games.  Rating (5/10 = failure): 9.5 Multiplayer: Yes (2) Completion: 23 hrs Cards: Yes Cloud: Yes Cost: 20 USD  Well what can I say? If you loved the Trouble with Clones DLC from Saints Row the Third (which was awesome, btw), this game will absolutely cater to that, and I love it.  This game will no doubt feel 'cheap' how they decided to reuse Steelport in its entirety. And because of that, the whole game basically feels like a giant DLC for SR3. But that shouldn't detract you from getting it. There's still a ton that went into the game. And really, how often did you get to appreciate the city from their roofs in SR3?  Regarding the story - if the Matrix were made as an adult comedy game, I'm pretty sure this game would be the result. The game parodies a good number of things, such as Metal Gear Solid, but by far the most prominent is the Matrix universe. Just the fact that the game introduces aliens in the first few minutes should be an indication as to how silly this game is. And they take it seriously, too (sorta)! It's all in good fun. I particularly like the ending to the Enter the Dominatrix DLC. It's a bit annoying that you can't redo main story missions. Hence if you got the bad ending, you're stuck with it. One complaint about the game is how ALL of the side missions have some introductory two-line speech about how doing the mission will help break the simulation. It doesn't. Why even include those lines? Heck you can even do those activities before the side missions are given to you, which skips the dialogue altogether.  Half the game is mini-games; the other half... is collecting collectibles. For real, there are about a thousand data clusters to collect, and trying to grab them all is one heck of a time sink. Fortunately it's fun using super powers, so it's not completely bad. Just don't do it all in one go to maintain your sanity.  In a game where it's faster and safer to outpace a car on foot, it's odd that carjacking still exists, and is even required for some side missions, but I can't really complain, as it does help slow things down to make you appreciate how nice it is to go all Neo.  For the most part the scenery is nice. It's Steelport, but with altered street signs, some new alien structures, and annoying video interference that just has to remind you every 30 seconds of the world that you're in. The perma-red skies irritate the hell out of me, as it does in all games that do that, but you can change the colors once you beat it. I really wish you could change these sooner, and get rid of the interference thing altogether.  One feature that isn't outright stated is that you can turn the radio on at most times during gameplay using the < or > keys. Shrek's Row 4 is a fantastic game all around. They took Shrek's Row the Third and shifted into maximum ogredrive. It is stylized with multiple layers much like an onion or an ogre and has a plethra of orge-wordly powers for you to crush your enemies with. The soundtrack is other songs that were already made but placed into the game because Shrek said so, much like the first movie. The story follows Shrek as he embarks on a journey to take back his swamp and crush Farquaad and his cult of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ socks who fail to realize Shrek as their one true ogrelord while also ♥♥♥♥ing everybody he doesn't murder first (and on one occasion he does both) with a weapon that fires dubstep so wannabe the hipsters have even more reason to complain about the game for being Shrek-tacular. If you liked Shrek's Row 2 or The Third, you will like this as it combines both of the previous spiritual journey's types and structures of humogre into a perfect, Shrek-tacular blend of clever parody and sex jokes.  Shrek is Love, Shrek is life.  10/10 donate your money to Shrek right now.

I really enjoyed Saint's Row 2 and the third, and this one took things to a whole new level that made it epic!   This borrows from so many other movies and games along with many pop culture references that its often hard to keep track whats from what. And it is because of that nature of the game that I was never quite sure what was going to happen next, but one thing I did know is that no matter what would happen, the game was going to leave me either surprised, shocked confused, excited, or laughing after one of the many hilarious bits throughout the story.   While there are a few intense and serious moments similar to SR 2, for the most part, the games doesn't take itself too seriously. The outrageous gameplay is all about having fun while taking out your enemies in the most stylish way possible while using your powers. There are a lot of quest to do but you are never forced to do most of them and you can play at your own pace as you unlock new items, powers and customize your character, crew, vehicles and weapons.   This game is possibly the most fun I have ever had in any open world game and is a real joy to play and when you add a friend into the mix for co-op, it makes the experience even better.

Anyone who tells you this game is bad is either lying or doens't know how to enjoy this game. Like the last one, the only way to really enjoy the game is to take nothing seriously and just have fun, and that's really easy in this game.  Once you get past the opening segment and start getting your super powers it's an absolute blast. You can't have multiple powers available at once, but you can easily switch between them, and traversal powers like super speed and super jump are always at your disposal, eliminating the need for any vehicle once you level up stamina and get certain upgrades, but you'll get in vehicles anyway for the sweet neon cars and monster-truck versions of pre-existing vehicles, and if you get the presidential dlc you get the most hilarious jet which you will probably not be able to resist riding around in either.  Add to that all the sci-fi movie and game references (the whole thing is almost a parody of Mass effect, with 'loyalty missions' for all of your homies, romance options [where all you do is shag, but like I said: parody] and of course the space, 3rd-person shooter theme) and throw in ways to feel closer to all of your friends, which was unexpected but endearing when you start learning how they cope with the situations they are or have been in, and their views on you. Put all that together and what you have is a game that will give you hours upon hours of entertainment. The worst thing I could find about this game is that they (SPOILERS) killed Oleg. I guess when Deep Silver bought the franchise they took some kind of poll to figure out who everyone's favorite characters were and went with them, which explains why Kinzie is such a central character this time around. Still doens't explain why Oleg (whom I always thought was wildly popular) was 'cut' (possibly to remove the brute class altogether, which is also a weird/dumb play,) so that and not only Angel's death, but complete absence from the story were the worst things about the game for me. If you have a sense of humor and want to play something that's just a fun, dumb good time, this game is a must-buy. I'd suggest picking up the edition that comes with all the dlc which is nearly all costumes and cosmetics(which is all dlc should be,) with some weapons, vehicles, and even some side-missions thrown in for end-game content, as it just makes the game more fun/silly, and it's a fairly common thing to go on sale. Hell, if it's on sale then the Saint's franchise pack is also probably on sale, which I'd suggest even more. So get out there and see how corny/silly/badass you can be gosh-darnit!

It's worth noting that the story of this game is heavily connected with the previous installments of the franchise, so If you want to fully enjoy that aspect of SR 4 it'd be better that you have played from SR 1 to 3. The only negative point that I have against this game is that the options of customization of your characters (appearance and clothes) were almost the same that in Saints Row the third. Saints Row IV is an odd game, even for Saint's Row standards. Entertaining humour filled with refferences to everything from Star Wars, to the Matrix, Mass Effect and more. I think that's one of the main points if you'll enjoy this game or not, meaning the humour. Because honestly the game doesn't really have much else going for it.   The enemy AI actually feels 'dumbed down' from Saints row 3 which is conciderably odd as SR4 is obvously copy-pasted from SR3. This also means that the gameworld brings little to almost nothing new compared to SR3. If you played SR3 you will laugh at all the re-used assets. The overall gameworld feels familiar with the exception of a few hovering alien towers.  One of the focuses of the game is on activities or 'side quests'. A lot of the activities return such as Mayhem or my personal favorite insurance fraud (Mayhem is pretty much just blow things up and insurance fraud encourages you to take large amounts of damage and combo it up) and of course new ones such as Platforming Rift which is pretty much what you'd imagine it to be (platforming) and TK-Mayhem (cause mayhem and destruction using telekinesis).   The game does a bad job explaining what you can and can not do. Such as forcing you to use an ability or do something spesificly only to explain to you a few minutes later how to perform that spesific action. To be fair I believe this only happend twice(?) in the game.   Most of the superpowers are surprisingly not satisfying to use. It's clear that SR3 wasn't made for superpowers which makes it an odd combo at times. Being able to blow up eight+ enemies with a simple use on the 'force' power tree, having life stealing bullets and powers also makes this game incredibly easy, repetive and boring. Even your punches are super powered which means if you want a challenge you have to tune up the difficulty and use guns instead of punching (yeah sounds weird).  The story is ... I'm not entierly sure what to call it. Earth gets invaded by aliens and you (the president) get trapped inside a simulation to help defeat the aliens. The story will bring you through very familiar places from SR1, SR2 and SR3 (don't worry, if you haven't played those, it's still easy to follow what's going on).   I'll defiently recommend this game, but only if you are the kind of person that's looking for a humourus and 'less than traditional story'. If you're not into the Saints Row type of humour then I don't think you should buy this game. As the story can't carry a game.  + Audio Good controller support Humour Plenty of different activities (allthough some are quite similar) Unusual story Car Handling (allthough there's no reason to drive a car) Relatively short game (most of the time will be spendt on activities)  - Enemy AI Re-used game from SR3 Re-used assets everywhere Lack of costumisation Brings surprisingly little new from SR3 Unsatisfying combat Jumps and gaps in the story

Possible spoilers ahead.  Saints Row IV was hilarious with just the right amount of a good story mixed with fun, crazy gameplay. It had moments that made me laugh, made me cry, made my heart race from the drama, and I just can't get over how much I love it. I really wish/hope that they come out with a fifth one- I want the story to finish or give a little more closure. What happens next? Do they time travel for the rest of their lives? Find another planet to live on? Restore humanity? Send a blowup doll terraforming machine that Kinzie makes into the atmosphere of a new planet? I need to know, because- even though they're fictional characters- it's one of those feelings that won't go away where you wish happiness and good things upon the characters because they seem so real and fun. Even if they'd act like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s once in a while, they have charm. 10/10 and that's my final offer.

Prior to release, many people thought Saints Row IV was simply going to be 'Saints Row: The Third but with superpowers'. Well, they were right and it's AWESOME. But it's also a lot more than that.  Let's get the obvious out of the way: the superpowers are stupidly fun to play with. Leaping over whole buildings, throwing cars (or anything really) with your mind, and punching the ground so hard you create a nuclear explosion are ALL things you can look forward to doing in SRIV. The city of Steelport is much more fun to play around in compared to SR3, but the ability to make it from one side of the map DOES have the effect of making it seem a tad small.  The writing is FANtastic. I honestly can't remember the name of the villain in SR3 but SRIV gives us the hilarious Zinyak, who is so easy and fun to hate. I played with Laura Bailey's voice and she absolutely kills it as the Boss. One complaint though is that there are less cutscenes than SR3, which may have been an attempt to 'cut the BS' in favor of just getting to the gameplay but I quite liked the cutscenes. The few that there are are better than ever, however. 'What are you going to do, bravado me to death?'  The story missions remain the funnest thing to do in the game. The side missions have survived the transition, but adjusted for the inclusion of superpowers. Insurance Fraud is a must play, considering you can ragdoll yourself over entire buildings. One HUGE flaw however: you still cannot replay story missions and this kills me. Many of the story missions are pure manic fun and I'd love to go back and fly through space to the tune of 'what is love?' but I can't without starting a fresh file.   SRIV was one of my favorite releases by FAR in 2013. It has the outward appearance of a game that was made by people who well and truly stopped caring a long time ago, but the truth is that they care an awful lot about giving you the most stupidly fun experience that they humanly can, and it shows.

Volition had labeled it 'the climactic chapter' of the Saints Row franchise, and having played through it, I can see why. Holy crap. Think of every open-world game you've played since the first Saints Row game came out. Now think about the best elements of those all mixed into a game that I feel strangely compelled to describe with the phrase 'cataclysmically ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic', as I'm not sure lesser terms will do.  Now, I'm not saying this is the game to end all games. There are quite a few repetitive side quests, it only took me about 16 hours to finish all missions (not all challenges, though) and WAY too many Mayhem missions of infinitely stale varieties (Steer a tank! Fly a UFO! Throw a ball!), but there are enough totally badass moments to make up for those. The plot is strangely engaging for the premise, really giving players a look back at the true natures of the Saints and their foes, through their nightmares and their greatest triumphs. Plus, there's a telekinesis system that actually grabs the damn thing you want it to, unlike every other game I've seen try it.  The radio selection is subpar, but the original soundtrack is bountiful, and the licensed songs that do get used are perfectly timed. The game takes all its blatant parodies in spectacular stride, while still coming across as a Saints Row story first and foremost. Those who've stuck with the series since the beginning will find a lot to love in returning content, as will PC users who had to start with SR2 (you're really going to just be confused for, like, two missions, in that case).  The powers just work well, though the game's repeated insistence on taking them away from you for missions gets a bit grating eventually. There are also some major glitches at this stage, but programmers and modders are fast at work on them. Basically, as with The Third, if you can't get past something, turn down your resolution.  All in all, this game is simply irresistible. If you haven't played the game, you probably don't get what I'm referring to. More incentive to play it.

If you have played Saints Row The Third, you have a general knowledge of the concept of Saints Row IV. This third person action/adventure/comedy/superhero satire of society and Grand Theft Auto is an absolute blast to mess around in, but falls flat in some other key areas.  The gameplay in Saints Row IV is very much like that of Saints Row the Third, with the same weapons classes, same shooting styles, in fact, the only things that make it different is the addition of super powers and the new weapons. You either use an overwhelming amount of firepower or your supernatural abilities to lay waste to the aliens that assault you as well as some other enemies. Combat is just as fun as in SR The Third, but don't expect much in the way of innovation. The one area that is very different from SR The Third is with the new superpowers. These are a heck of a lot of fun to play around with, and I have gotten probably at least half of all my kills with these skills. While these abilities keep the game fresh and help stop stagnation, it isn't enough to justify getting IV over The Third just on gameplay merits alone.  While story hasn't been as critical to the Saints Row series since the last game, it still has one and should be discussed. I won't provide any spoilers that have happened as of yet, but the plot is fairly interesting, and filled with a bunch of good laughs and is mostly satirical, and not to be taken seriously in any way. This serves to the rest of the goofy game's benefit, but players of Saints Row 2 that are hoping to a return to that story will be very much let down. One thing that I noticed about the optional side missions in the game is that they are extremely repetive mini-game chains. It seems like they are almost like an RPG's quests, taking you from one miscellaneous mission to the next in persuit of unlocking a new power or costume, while not pushing the story further in any way. Even though I was dissapointed that there was no connection to the game's story with all of these mssions, I found myself doing each of them one after another to gain more power and try to get the gold in each minigame. Many people may tire of these quests's repetitiveness, but you will end up doing them anyways and they aren't bad.  The graphics in Saints Row IV are not mind blowing, even on maxed settings, but the cartoonish atmosphere (at least to me) fits the game quite well. The aethstetic that the virtual city provides does make it seem like you are in a computer simulation, although the eternal night and shimmering textures do get kind of annoying at some points. Another thing that I have noticed is that the game is not well optimized for the PC, and even on my powerful hardware I noticed frequent framerate drops when moving very quickly or jumping very high and looking down. I guess it could be expected that looking at a large portion of a city from above would reduce one's framerate, but even when running through the streets I noticed dips as low as 40 FPS on my GTX 770, which is weird when I have played better looking games that run consistently better (Crysis series, Battlefield 3, Assassin's Creed IV) that also have large AI and real player counts in view.   To conclude this review: If you were a fan of Saints Row the Third and crave more mayhem similar to that game, then SRIV is a great buy. However, if you are still fine with mucking about in The Third or didn't care for it, I would second guess this silly game's buy. My final verdict for this game is an 8 out of 10, good fun.

Vehicles are present but you'll hardly use them, since your super speed and super jump will allow you to go over buildings without a hitch, not to mention doing so is actually way faster than any vehicle. Anyway, if you don't mind a sandbox game where the story is a big ♥♥♥♥ you to conventions and isn't afraid of some dirty jokes, you'll like this game.

Saints Row IV is an open world game that continues the story of the Third Street Saints by elevating their status to the highest level - the leaders of the free world. After a catastrophic alien invasion occurs where the aliens trasnport the Saints to a bizarro-Steelport simulation, you must fight to free humanity from alien grandaddy Zinyak's mental grasp by ultiziling gargantuan superpowers. Escape the simulation that's trapped the Saints crew, or die trying. The consistent thrill of Saints Row IV is how it constantly, eagerly, happily, accommodatingly asks you “Hey, how do you want to break the game now?” And for a game so colossal, so occasionally dumb, so often colossally sharks-with-laser-beams-on-their-heads-that-can-also-breathe-fire-and-fly-and-turn-invisible-and-you-can-even-ride-them dumb, what an incredibly smart thing to do with an open world, a franchise, and a story. There's some uneven bits but Saints Row IV captures what video games should be or at least strive to be: Fun. And that exuberance of playing around in a big sandbox with almost no limits placed on the player while spinning an entertaining yarn that fully acknowledges that it's a game should put Saints Row IV on a lot of Game of Year lists. A fantastic game, keeping up the series' tradition of giving players a wide open world and the tools to go absolutely bonkers within it. It's hilarious, it's action-packed, and most of all, its fun to play.

The next (il)logical progression in the Saint's Row series... We are now a super-powered POTUS... *facepalms*  In all honesty, the game is pretty good, and the story, dialog and characters are just as sill (if not more so) than before, so you're bound to be laughing out loud more than a few times as you play. The downside is that the game is almost a carbon-copy of SR3. Yes, there are some changes; no cribs just gateways to the ship, cosmetic changes to the city, etc... but you're still in Steelport, or a least a version of it, so there's nothing new to explore. There are also less activites, and instead of how they were in SR3, where each had it's own goal and that was that, now they all have 3 levels of completion; Bronze, Silver and Gold, so instead of a new mission each time you're replaying the same levels over again to get higher scores, which gets grind-like after a while of trying to score Gold on all instances of an activity to complete a Challenge and get the reward.  As for DLCs, aside from Enter The Dominatrix and How the Saints Save Christmas, their all cosmetic stuff that gets old fast, so unless you *really* want them, you can ignore them.  Replay value here is low, since there are no alternate solutions to some mission like there were in SR3 (the ones linked to the achievements). And aside from two achievements linked to play time and playing as both a Male and Female character for a certian amount of time, you'll probably just beat the game in co-op and single player once or twice and that'll be that.  Now, I know everything I've said has been harsh, but thats just the truth. The game itself is great, and unless Volition changes their minds, this is the last Saints Row game we're ever gonna see, so if you liked the series, at least pick this up when it's on sale and give it a go.  EDIT: This may not be the last Saints Row game, but I'm not sure. As far as I remember, I read several articles on this being the last SR game we'll see. However, given how there's still a decent community for this game, from modders to players, and the devs are willing, we may see a SRV... but I wouldn't hold my breath.

Damn good game, 9/10. Didn't change much up from SR3, used the same graphics and engine even. This time around, it's more like Saints Row meets Prototype, not with the mutant people killing virus and what not, but instead you gain awesome super powers such as fireballs, superjump, telekenisis, etc. The story is pretty good, but if you look at it in a whole 1/2 of it is filler, as in all you do is rescue 7 of your friends from the simulation. All of which are in different scenarios (their worst nightmare, litterally), but the thought process is the same. So yeah, without the filler this game could potentially be just DLC for SR3, but the change in gameplay via superpowers makes it worth it. Very rarely will you ever use a man made gun, or even drive a vehicle for that matter. Tons of collectibles, the usuall side quests, and challanges to boot to give you tons of gameplay time so long as you don't just skip everything and just do main story missions only. As usual per the series the game is full of 'wtf awesome!' moments that have you sitting back and applauding the writers for thinking of this ♥♥♥♥!  ***Side Note***  The 'Saints Save Christmas DLC' is a MUST get. I am normally against most DLC, but Tim Burton would give two thumbs up for this. The North Pole level alone has got to be the most demented, off beat, ♥♥♥♥ed up Santa land you have ever seen!

No doubt SR4 can be considered as a DLC for SR3. The main story would be longer. Moreover we cannot understand the purpose of doing side quests that get similar and boring at the same time. Most of them consist of the following format: hack the store, then upload the virus, then come to the ship and see me. These can be completed before the final main quest in order to gain the related achievement. On the other hand the game is not rough as much as the previous ones. So I suggest you buy the game just if it's at an enormous discount.

I'll admit, Saints Row IV is turning out better than I thought. Though one and two have a special place in my heart, Saints Row IV has done a better job so far that The Third. One of the best introduction to a game in my opinion, for starters. You're placed right into the heat of combat, without the slow paced action that was annoying at first in the other Saints. The enviornment in the virtual world is AWESOME, I really don't mind the day and night shifts with how it looks! The guns feel like there was no change from the third, but it has some more customization with the camo. Wish there was more. Not a huge fan with the super powers, though. I stick with my guns rather than running around using the same sprint take down. It just feels like game is way too easy if I just use the powers. Hillariously easy. Even though I hate using the super powers in combat, but its great not relying on a car or plane. With all that said, Saints Row IV is turning out way better than I had expected. It just sucks to accept the fact that we probably won't get our old gangsta Saints again. However, A+ to not sticking to the same formula and having new twists to each game.

Saints Row has progressed a lot from the days of the first Saints Row when it was an unabashed GTA clone. Things started to change with Saints Row 2, and the franchise really hit its stride with Saints Row: The Third. Saints Row IV builds upon the comedy and outrageousness of its predecessor and the results are great. While the venue is familiar, the action is amped up with super powers and comic weapons. The crew is back, and that is a good thing, as the characters and personalities that made Saints Row: The Third so enjoyable are as good as ever. If you can appreciate a game that doesn't take itself too seriously, and features over-the-top action that disregards physics and common sense, look no farther.

Honestly this game is just so much fun!  It is hard to imagine how they will make Saints Row V better or as much fun as this one was but I am looking forward to seeing what they do with it for sure! :)  I loved the other SR games, I loved this one that much more!  Bring on V I say!

This is part 4 of an awesome Saints Row series. Somewhat similar to Saints Row 3 with added content, improved graphics and new story. Open world sandbox, action RPG with a lot of shooting and/or melee weapon combat. I call this GTA on drugs. It's off the chains crazy with a lot of humor and stupidity. Awesome character design, great visuals and incredible voice acting talent. A lot of weapon customization and upgrade, clothing, car modifications apart from missions, side missions, activities and co-op madness with friends. At any point don't take this game seriously, you've been warned, enjoy.

I loved Saints Row 3. I also love this game so far.   Saints Row 4 for me is like GTA, just more humourous, easy-going and fun. The addition of 'aliens' in this game adds to the fun, which is what I like. Althought it doesn't feel much like Saints Row 1 or 2 anymore, it's like a huge expansion to Saints Row 3, more wild and more over-the-top.  One of the problems, however, for many people is just how OTT this game is. Yes, you are supposed to be a 'Saint' - a run and gun killing machine in a gang of America. But that isn't what this game is even more. Saints Row 3 is the middle-line between serious and fun. Saints Row 2 is the serious game, and Saints Row 4 is the fun one. Personally, I prefer Saints Row 4 over the other two, as it is just a great game with good gameplay, engaging story and wild powers.   9/10.

Going into this after Saints Row 3, I had no idea what to expect except for what I had heard from reviews and videos talking about the game. Right off the bat, the writing and over-the-top humor got me laughing more than SR3 ever could, and the intro itself was very well done. At first, the game does go a bit slow after you finish the first third of the opening missions prior to entering Steelport. Things do pick up right after the opening, however, when you get your first set of superpowers. A lot of people complained that the superpowers made things too easy. Personally, the game is still difficult with the powers, though I recommend setting the difficulty to hardcore for some real challenge. The interaction between you and your homies is funny to listen to, as well as their interactions with Zinyak, the alien leader.  The music choice is awesome. What is Love, The Touch and How We Do It are great tracks to listen to while beating up aliens, and it further increases the fun when you can listen to the music on foot (unlike SR3 where you had to be in a vehicle).  There are a few problems with the game, though. A majority of the extra missions get repetitive, almost always being a destruction-based minigame, followed by a clear the area segment and then returning to the ship to claim your reward. Some of the rewards are saitisfying, like the Dubstep Gun, but the missions get too repititive to want to do them all consistantly. The use of powers make vehicles a bit useless unless you're one to cause old-style mayhem ala SR3. Unless you have Superpowered homies, it even makes the use of calling homies useless, as you are a one-man powerhouse from the get-go. It's a shame because you get alot more in homie selection and vehicle customization.  Aside from that, the game has MANY more pros than cons, and I recommend this game in every way possible. If you want to play an open-world superhero game with great humor, this is the game for you

Is SRIV worth playing? 49.99? 20 or less?  Yes, no, yes.  Is SRIV fun?  Yes  Are the new features fun?  Yes  Is SRIV a good game?  Yes  Is SRIV a good sequel?   NO   REASONING / SPOILERS BELOW: Don't read if you haven't played SRIV for at least a few hours -----------------------------  I enjoyed my time in the virtual world of SRIV but the same things I liked are what make it a bad sequel. Within the first few hours of play, the current world of saints row is blown up in an attempt to keep up with the power creep of each release. In SR1 you fight for the streets; SR2 for the city; SR3 for the island; SRIV for the world; SRV for the universe?. So thanks to their increasing of the stakes, SRIV had no where to go but up in terms of size/wackiness but they went too far and destroyed the world   (literally)   of Saints Row in favor of a more configurable reality. This new 'world' is one that allows for super powers and other things to occur without it being 'law-defying' but this new mechanic overshadows and effectively ruins the established gameplay mechanics from the older games which they still tried to cram in.   Driving/Customizing  - Tons of fun to find your ride and trick it out.. This is made useless thanks to super speed/Jump-gliding  Shooting  - Super powers do more damage and use a regenerating ammo. After a few hours you can essentially stop using guns altogether. (Ammo becomes infinite much later)  Gun Upgrades  - Same as shooting, super powers upgrade and become practically infinite.  Melee  - Now this one they actually did a good job on. They integrated the new 'super powered' melee moves that you could augment with later powers.  If they spent time and thought it out, I bet they could have found a way for the super powers and old mechanics to co-exist better but in the end they left them there to rot.   Now if they would have marketed it differently, I may have let it slide. As an Expansion: It would have just been viewed as a refreshing change to shake up the gameplay As a 'titled' release (EX: Saints Row: The Power-ing): Same as expansion As a 'NUMBERED' release: It is an unwanted revamp to an already fun formula.  The reason why a numbered release pisses me off is it implies the events of the game are of the main story and not some side branch. This means the next game will have to continue where SRIV left off and honestly, the SRIV devs did SR5 no favors in terms of a lead in. They could ignore everything that happened in IV and treat it like a side branch or a dream or something but doing so would just prove the previous game should have never been 4.  -----------  All ranting aside, for ~20 bucks for ~16 hours is a pretty good deal and definitely worth the purchase if you like the crude humor of Saints Row and the crackdown-esque gameplay.. just ignore that it is a Saints Row sequel if it bugs you as much as me.   (Also hunting orbs is too damn addictive)

The game is genuinely good and fun to play, but it is an open world game. As such, repetitive gameplay is a staple of the game that must be acknowledged.  If you're completely new to Saint's Row, then imagine GTA with a slapstick sense of humor rather than a dark one. If you've played 3, then this is going to feel like nothing has changed. Specifically, the world is reskinned and the super powers from the DLC are the only 'new' mechanic that differentiates this entry.  If your experience with Saint's Row is either the origingal or 2, then be prepared for a very huge tonal shift. Whereas the original entries are GTA knock-offs, this it more like a clone decided to steal a gallon of nitrous oxide and fall into a vat of chemicals. The resultant monster is funny at times, depressing at others, yet thoroughly worth your time.    As far as DLC goes....maybe wait for the complete pack to go on sale. Most of the DLC is just character clothing, with the occasional item thrown in. My experience is that Gat out of Hell is the only really great content worth seeking out on its own, but given what happened with 3 you won't have to wait too long before everything will be put out in one discounted pack.
