Still has the incredibly boring, bland and dull world that SRIII had, but this time you have superpowers? Well, about those: Some activities that use superpowers are great fun, examples including that Genki telekinesis minigame, Blazin', Telekinesis(?) Rift, Speed Rift, and Insurance Fraud, but a lot of activities and missions, in particular the combat aren't much fun. The combat can be fun at times, but often it's all stiff and awkward, and it has those typical lategame action game tropes where there's stupid shields and you can only use particular powers or weapons against particular enemies which just slow big fights down. There is one particularly fun combat sequence near the end which is in VR, but in general the combat isn't very fun. What makes people like this game is the fact that it has a bunch of fun setpieces and missions. Other sandbox games, I feel, though, have more impactful missions because everything is less over the top. Great superhero games, too, have more memorable missions and more fun navigation because the world is more normal (i.e Spiderman 2, Ultimate Spiderman, Crackdown).  This game gets a very unenthusiastic reccommendation.

I would write a full review, but I don't think I could really do this game justice. This is, by far, the DUMBEST game I've ever played and I LOVE IT. Finally breaking away from its muddy, too-serious GTA roots, SR4 is an over-the-top, wacky, and downright fun to play game. Volition understands that people want either a good story, or fun gameplay, so they threw the concept of reality out the window and made a fun game with a crappy story, because like Platinum games, Volitions wants gameplay to come first. I'm not saying story is bad, as an avid RPG player I love a good story, but I also know when story needs to take a back seat to fun gameplay. In summary, come to SR4 for fun gameplay, not a good story, and just let yourself get immersed in how stupid it is, you'll have a grand old time!

What an entertaining game!!! I haven’t had this much fun in a game for a while. Not safe to play around the kids, lots of violence and language - but in a hilarious way. I paid $20 for it, and SR4 was worth every penny. I definitely will play through it again at a later date to explore more and find what I’ve missed. I haven't played any of the previous SR titles but after this I want to try them.   SR4 is basically a mix of gameplay from GTA and Batman Arkham City, wrapped up in a Matrix-like story. You are trapped in a virtual environment, which gives great story-based excuse to randomly destroy stuff, run over people, and also have super powers (as opposed to GTA where you just do it to be an a$$).   The game has an excellent soundtrack, hilariously woven in with the missions and story (youtube: “Saints Row nuclear Aerosmith”). At a later point in time after rescuing a homie, you and he are battling through hordes of bad guys together to the tune of “The Boys are Back in Town.”   The story itself is fun and quite entertaining, and gives you the opportunity to fight with your superpowers in the virtual world, then without them in the real world. You get to save humanity, fight aliens, struggle to save your friends, and “romance” (f!ck) them afterwards, if you so choose. You’ll leap over tall buildings (or run up them), smash into the ground to damage everything in the area, throw fire, ice and shoot electricity, use telekensis to pick up and throw vehicles, and cause general mayhem and destruction in order to crash the virtual simulation so you can break out your homies and take down the aliens that run it all.  Graphics are pretty good, nothing groundbreaking but more than sufficient to make the game look nice. The gameplay and sounds are excellent. The voice acting is superb, the characters are fun and believable, and you have a multitude of options for your character aside from the usual physical customizations, including different voice styles and tones. You can even select “the scroob” (SpaceBalls) as your gang’s “thing” they do to taunt.   One comment about DLC’s – there are tons available for this game, but all they do is add more (themed) costumes and weapons. The game already has lots of choices for costumes and weapons. I want to buy a DLC that gives me more story to play through.   The story, gameplay and audio make this game superb. Its high ratings and reviews are well earned.   EDIT: Steam censors

Cons -Took less than 2 days to finish.  -Single player is boring and extremely lackluster. -Weapons are unimpressive, despite customization -superpowers eventually corrode gameplay value after a while -plot is improvised at best, despite being an SR game. -replayability value is nearly non-existant -condensed with movie/game references & facepalm worthy jokes -graphics are exactly the same ones from SR3, even in DX11 -the open world in which most of the gameplay takes place is the same  city from SR3  Pros +Some nostalgic factor added to fans of SR2 +Lots of action & slightly thrilling moments at times +Some outfits are better than SR3's  Bottom line: Having finished SR3, I was expecting at least something equally as playable in a more or less long run, but I was disappointed by this refurbished DLC made a standalone sequel, just to put a $60 tag on it when it was released. It's single player duration is so laughable with little practice you can get to finish it in a free weekend, despite you don't get to play the even lesser lived DLC that will surely come in the future as a bundle. I wouldn't recommend this game even to those who didn't play any previous Saints Row game, since even SR3 has better Sp/Coop and replayability value.

I am somehow mesmerised by the 'very positive' reviews. I have to say, I loved SR2 and SR3, and I was all game for SR4 being more ridiculous and funny. But I just couldn't enjoy it, and I really tried, finished the game to find out it just mediocre. This could be fun as a side story or DLC for few hours, but It definitely doesn't have content for stand alone game.  1. For those familiar with previous games, SR4 have completely different feel to it. You don't get that 'gang' feeling and there is no reason to actually  care  about the city. 2. Superpowers ruin a lot of gameplay. I know it is reason many people like this game, I might be exception, but I actually enjoyed previous games because of those little things like driving, finding new things, exploring. It also makes everything too easy. I don't wanna be unkillable (at least you can always run like a rabbit) and crush everything in sight instantly (more or less). 3. It actually wasn't funny. There were few fine scenes, but that's about it. Without characters like   Gat and Zimos  , there is so much you can do, right? 4. It's repetitive, and I mean a lot. At least that's my opinion.  -> SR4 might be for you, if you enjoy 'god-like' openworld. If you want just fool around, go ahead.  -> If you're looking for good story, more balanced world, and  some  funny moments, play SR3 instead.  -> For those who like rougher, more gangster like stories, SR2 is the best choice.  My recommendation: If you are unsure, watch some actual gameplay video for half an hour, you'll find out quickly if it appeals to you or not. :)

After hours of changing my mind about this fun, flamboyent game, i've finally come to a decision on it; and, judging by the gameplay, the aesthetics and the nostalgic, comical flashbacks pinpointed throughout the game, i've decided that I like it.  Saints Row IV is a very entertaining game, and after completing the game and some very fun side quests, I was a little disappointed, I have to admit. Why? Saints Row IV lacks the seriousness and the entertaining gang-banger theme that Saints Row I, II, and III had. However, I believe that after Saints Row II, The much loved, acclaimed Saints Row series took a turn for the worst, after fun, bright graphics were replaced by a stupid amount of blow up dolls and references to other games. Saints Row IV does not feel like a Saints Row game, as the gangsters we enjoyed killing are replaced by Aliens which we don't get that much enjoyment out of.  The customizability is poor, and the need for cars is next to nothing as it's replaced by super sprint and jumping so high that it's hard to land on the thing you want to, nevertheless, it's a fun game.  My rating? 6/10

When I first saw saints row IV, I thought it was going to be awful, I couldn't be more wrong. The entire game was a blast, start to finish. While the graphics are sub par, the gameplay is excellent. The superpowers add a whole new depth of gameplay and certainly make the experience a lot more enjoyable. The story isn't half bad either. The best part of this game, are all the refrences. There are so many references; Metal Gear Solid, Star Fox 64, Star Wars, DOOM 3, Aliens, Street Fighter, Star Trek, and more! These refrences made the game a lot more enjoyable, adding to the humor, making me laugh. Overall this game is fantastic.  8.5/10

This game seems very lazy. Most of the content is from SRTT and it's DLC. The only 'new' things added were some digital graphics(which got old real fast), some new models for enemies, and the Wardens. Those are pretty much the only new things this game brings.  Before you say 'well this game brought super powers in!' keep in mind they already did that in SRTT with DLC. They did polish it up and made it the main feature, but that's it. It's not new.  They did fix the weapons from SRTT though. In SRTT the guns did practically no damage to enemies and the enemies were bullet sponges.   One of the biggest things that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off about this game was the Enter the Dominatrix DLC. That was a steaming pile. It was just using base game materials for most of the DLC. Then they announce a giant monster is coming and then cut to a story board fight where Birk kills it. You can say they did that as a joke, but the way I see it is that they were too lazy/cheap to actually make it happen. I'm not sure why they brought Donnie into this. They didn't bring Dex back because they thought it would alienate new players, but they bring in a minor character like Donnie? Dex was a big character in SR1.  The base game blows. The side missions are unbearable as each one is the same. It's either 'clear out that area', 'assasinate that virus', or 'hold off this painfully long wave fight'. The side missions were so damn repetitve. It was agonizing. There was little incentive to do them anyways. The most you could get was unlocking a door to teleport to. Big whoop. You can glide there faster than you can find a portal, leave the world, go back in and warp there. The one sie mission that stands out is the super powered arena fight, but that blows. It's not fund having to fight people who have super powers when all they do is jump far away for no reason and telekentically throw things at you with pinpoint accuracy which makes you ragdoll. The side mission rewards were not worth the trouble. I would rather not upgrade my guns than have to do the same side mission I just did 3 times already.  The Warden fights were far too annoying. Every single warden fight could only be ended when you button mashed like crazy. That can tire your fingers out quick if you do it frequently. Wardens deterred me from doing most things because I didn't want to deal with the hassle. They aren't even hard to fight. They are just annoying. Especially early game when you have to fight them with the crappy telekenesis power. They wuld have been much more tolerable if they would die like in the training sims where they just pop.  They took out all of the cribs. Yes, I know they did that because Zin-yak wanted to 'break' them, but without safe houses, it was just city. No where else to go. I don't know why Volition keeps taking out interior buildings as they progress in their series. SR2 had so many enterable buildings. SR3 had significanly less. SRIV I think has 2(Kinzies old warehouse and the bar). I like to have buildings I can enter. It gets boring when all you do is kill on the street. There's nothing else to do. I liked being able to enter my crib and just sit around or jump off the roof.  I also hated how all the characters were aware it was a simulation, but still didn't really accept what that meant. The loyalty missions were painfully crappy. They knew those 'people' were AI, but still talked to them as if they were the real things. They knew they weren't real, but still acted like they were. King went as far as to give the AI Tanya a 'second chance' despite 'her' being a program meant to kill them and nothing more. The whole 'Tanya' AI was a load too. Why would an AI designed by the people who designed the entire simulation need to wrangle up some AI ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in a digital world? It made no sense. Another part was how they all thought Kinzie's warehouse was 'safe'. Not a single place is safe there. Zin-Yak can see and change anything he wants there. Kinzie knew this, but suddenly just ignores it. They were going to talk about their plan there instead of talking about it on the ship(which would have made a lot more sense).  Vehicles are useless. I don't know why so many of the DLC packs included vehcles. The moment you start gliding is the moment you never get in a car again. When you upgrade your running to the max, I'm pretty sure you run faster than any car and you have better handling and mobility. The garage is completely useless except for VTOLs.  All the DLC is laughable. They only include a few missions and useless features. The Christmas DLC was the most enjoyable(seems like they actually put a little effort into it with the whole Santa's workshop since it didn't use basegame materials), but it only added 3 missions that were painfully short. All together the DLC equals $30. Most of the DLC packs are completely useless. They add vehicles(which are useless the second you can glide), weapons skins(most are crap), and a few costumes(I wore none of them).  The most fun I had in the game(aside from the first experience with super powers) were the missions where you had to go to the real world and fight. Not the Mech missions. Those were very boring. I'm talking abut the missions where you were on foot. Unfortunately there are very few times you get to do this and you are stuck with 3 guns(unless you cheat some in).  The whole GAt thing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off. I hated how they killed him in 3, but they kept pushing that he died. Even Phillipe and Viola stated he was dead and they were right there. You think they would wonder why after they got knocked out that Gat was missing. Him being captured made no sense since in SR3 Phillipe and Viola always bring up how he died. Don't get me worng, I love Gat, but that's just bad how they did it. If you make a decision like that you should stick to it. Not screw with the story and have it make no sense.  The whole 'Fun Shaundi' character bothered me. She wasn't real, yet everyone acted as if she was. Shaundi(whom I hated since SRTT) would even talk to it as if it was her past self.   The Ship was boring and useless. There was nothing worth doing on it. The only times I ever went on it was when a mission told me to.  After you beat the game there is nothing to do. It gets real boring running around blowing things up. That's all you can do. The side missions are way too tedious to even consider fun. It was worse than SRTT after you beat it. At least in SRTT you could go to zombie island and kill zombies, mess around in your cribs, or fight gangs.   The thing that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most is that the game is basically SRTT.5. The whole game really should have been a DLC pack. Cut out the ridiculous repetitive side missions and the game is pathetically small(aka DLC sized). Even the map is frustrating. It's just the SRTT map with minor alterations(deleting the cribs, adding those annoying domes, those towers, and a few floating platforms). I hated the SRTT map. It was so boring. It was all industrial city. Nothing else. SR2 at least had variations. There was a clean upper class section, a ghetto, a suburban area, a mountain with trees, small islands off the shore that aren't connected by bridges, a trailer park, and much more. The SRTT map had 2 types of areas. Industrial and regular city.  A minor complaint, but of all things to NOT bring from 3, why did they not bring the zombies back? The zombie cheat would have made the game so much more tolerable. The zombies are the one thing that really pulls me to play SRTT again. If SRIV had zombies, I would play it more often since the weapons are far better than SRTT's weapons.   Don't get me wrong, I will still play the game, but I do not reccomend it. If you do insist on getting it, you should either get it used on a console without DLC(trust me, the DLC is NOT worth it) or get it on sale.

My recommendation is very half-hearted. From a technical perspective SR4 is superb. It's fast, the controls are intuitive, everything runs smooth as silk. But in Volition's quest to top SR3, they lost the soul, personality, and humor of the game. SR3 was over the top, but in an intelligent way. Parts were satire, others were parody, or puns. There was a story. There were characters. And there was game balance. SR4 feels like it was designed by a roomful of drunk frat boys whose contributions were along the lines of, 'Duh, huh. Let's, like, make it bigger and stuff. And let's make the alien say 'poop'! G-he, g-he, g-he.' The jokes and the one-liners fall flat. Vehicles, one of the joys of SR3, are completely worthless in SR4. You run faster than the fastest vehicle -- never mind if you jump, soar, or fly! -- and you can run through the toughest vehicle and destroy it. Heck, that's faster than shooting a rocket at it. The result is that while you couldn't pry my away from SR3 in my first playthrough, I find it hard to get motivated enough to do more than 30 minutes or so at a time in SR4 and I walk away feeling as if nothing actually happened.

Quite good for its price. I was told to avoid buying it because it was 'weird' and bad. Well, assuming it's less than 3€ in certain key shops, it's more than worth the money. It took for me about 22 hours to get 79%. The only remarcable 'con' is that it is no longer a 'classic' Saints Row game, talking about the meta-game itself. As soon as you get super powers, conduction and vehicles are useless 85% of the time. Maybe longer. Shooting is still important, but not as much as it used to be.  That said, the characters are back (Shaundi, Kinzie, Pierce... the saint flow!!). Dialogues are still great, as usual. Graphics are nice and performance is quite good (I ran it with my integrated GPU for few days and still got 60 FPS in low quality, so it's a 10/10 optimization).  The 'extras' (races, chaos, fraud...) are still there with some new missions, which I found to be great indeed. There are also lot of secondary quests, which were not great but neither bad. Just average. The plot was... good. Not awesome, but quite good I'd say. Better than expected for sure. You can still customize vehicles and your character, although you're not using much vehicles this time.  As I agree that SR3 was far, far better than this, I could not say if this is better than SR2, as it had a good plot, but it was unnecessary crude, as I see. This one has is own drama, but it has nothing to do with that grimm in SR2. I also found some characters to be unknown, as I didnt played SR1. That was kind of anoying, as playing SR2 wasn't a problem to me after playing SR3. Still managed to survive, tho.  So, things are like theese: Pros: +Nice dialogues, nice plot, nice Saint Flow. +Paul +Awesome optimizacion and nice graphics +Fast and therefore 'hard' movement. Races are quite more a deal than they were in previous games. +Paul +Charismatic antagonist +Weapons went mad this time. The are some masterpieces like the 'Dumbstepator', the 'hinflaray', a bacl hole machine...You even have a plundger thrower, god dammit!  Cons: -Vehicles are no longer worth your time -The game is VERY different to the other Saint series. I didnt found this bad, but many people do. -Some DLCs are very unbalanced. I bugged a main quest by accident, as I killed more than 60 guys with just 1 skill, killing the 'event proc' in the way.. On the other side, they include the 'América'. Firethrower, rocketlauncher and bullets... all at once! -Super powers? I liked them tho : ) -Paul. -You may find some characters unknown if you did not play the whole series. I did : (  All in all, and keeping in mind that you can get the game for less than 5 bucks, I think this game is more tan worth. Not only your money, but your time. Remember to make sure you play cooperative, you'll laugh double : )

The Saint’s Row franchise has been detaching itself from reality more and more, putting distance between it and the (relatively speaking) more grounded Grand Theft Auto games. After the generally cray-cray Saint’s Row: The Third, the question was how much further Volition – the main company behind the games – was willing to push the madness. Saint’s Row IV provides the answer in the form of aliens, virtual reality and superpowers. After a (near?) death experience set to the tune of Aerosmith’s ‘I don’t wanna miss a thing’, you end up as president of the US of A, just as aliens invade. You get thrown into a Matrix-like city where you start a resistance movement to save the last few remnant of mankind. How you can do this while closely monitored in a simulation that is at the Alien Overlord’s control is a bit fuzzy. But never mind coherence and plotholes. (Which the game is happy to point to itself.) This smartly stoopid sandbox game is actually the most entertaining superhero simulator I’ve played so far.  To start with the stoopid part; yes, the game is amazingly crass and juvenile. You can punt someone half-way down the street with a giant ♥♥♥♥♥, should you feel the need. Or you can give someone an anal probe if you were ‘lucky’ enough to score that particular bit of bonus content. But overall, the game has a unusually relaxed and pleasant attitude about sex and gender. You can pick a male body, combine it with a female voice and then cross-dress to your heart’s content. Sure, there are mostly naked female bodies on display, but male nudity gets just about equal time. My male alter-ego ended up enthusiastically performing a sexy/ridiculous stripper dance while nearly nude in a strip-club in front of a mixed clientele.  You can make a pass at all the people in the posse you put together over the course of the game – be they man, woman or droid. Nearly all will happily take you up on the offer, regardless of the gender-combination. My favorite exchange in this regard (paraphrased) is when you go “Hey, we shared so much, wanna add ‘casual sex’ to the list?” and your homie goes “Well, I normally don’t swing that way, but f*ck it, I’m down!” There is no depth or consequence to any of these interactions, but then consequences are not what the game is about. Mostly, this feature just pokes fun at the Mass Effect series, where you could romance your crewmates, with more gender limitations, but also with an actual effect on the story.  Saint’s Row IV is an exhilarating power fantasy – even more so than The Third. It’s not just about cathartic destruction, but also features a liberating freedom of movement. You will be running along a street at super-speed, sending cars to the left and right of you flying as you pass. You will ‘charge’ your jump as you race towards a tall building and then release the button at just the right moment to make yourself soar over it. If the building is too tall too jump over, then you just run up the side of it and jump off the top, gliding through the air to a different section of the city. I spent my first two hours of playtime just bouncing from rooftop to rooftop, collecting alluringly glowing ‘glitches’ scattered around the city, which are needed to upgrade your powers. There is something Zen-like and relaxing about it, even though you ultimately won’t want to bother collecting all 1000+ of them. The joy of simply zooming around wears off a little, but never fully goes away. I already experienced similar bounce-around collect-athons before in Prototype and Crackdown, but these were let down by the less appealing game around them. (I dropped out of both of them after a while.)  The superpowers in general are very well done. There’s telekinesis, you can send out various kinds of destructive blasts and you can punch into the ground with your first or – from the air – with your entire body, causing a variety of shockwave effects. The potential for causing mayhem is huge and you won’t have to feel morally conflicted about bystanders. Even within the videogame they aren’t real, just being part of a Matrix-like simulation you were thrown into. They’re doubly virtual. It’s just as well, as you are able to level whole cityblocks by the end of the game, if you made the effort to upgrade. I especially enjoyed the ability to set off chained explosions, which I only realised after a while was actually part of DLC I bought together with the main game (the ‘Element of Destruction Pack’). On the downside, it allows you to rip through sections of the game very quickly and without challenge. You may find yourself relying on it too much.  It’s interesting, though a bit disappointing, that the game takes your superpowers away for a lot of the main story missions, because you’d be too overpowered for them otherwise. So you’ll mostly use them within the city simulation to take over alien bases, do point-to-point races and platform your way around.  A lot of side-activities are recycled from the previous game, even if they now don’t fit all that well. Some of them wrestle you into a car to do some driving around, which feels restrictive as cars are slower than you are when running. There really doesn’t seem to be a use for cars apart from window dressing and to serve occasionally as a tool of destruction. Regardless, you can still ‘collect’ cars by driving them to a garage and upgrade them. You can also still call on homies to assist you in battle – another feature you will never need to use. But you can customize the look of these homies and upgrade them, if you want to. The superfluous stuff doesn’t detract from the experience, it just makes you wonder why it’s there.  I wouldn’t advise playing too much of the side-activities unless prompted. Most of the side-missions just have you play a selection of these activities in any case, so you will be getting an ample amount of them. And as some of them are recycled from the last game, they may feel familiar to begin with. Again taking inspiration from Mass effect 2, there are ‘loyalty missions’, to have you solidify your bond with your homies. Not completing all of these will result in a less than ideal alternate ending cutscene.  As I upgraded my graphics card between this game and its predecessor, comparing their look is tricky. But the city seemed more detailed and vibrant, full of interesting landmarks. It is mostly the same map, but feels like a wholly new experience because you’re not restricted to the roads. Sadly, the polish present in the main world is absent from the cutscenes. The lip-synching is awful at times and character animation can get a bit hokey and glitchy, especially the bits taking place on the spaceship that serves as your home base. Weirdly, your alter-ego looks better during regular gameplay. (For most of it, I made mine a dark-skinned muscleman with mutton chops, a blokey, UK voice and a Steampunk outfit.) I encountered two game-crashes when the game was switching to a cut-scene, requiring me to do part of the preceding levels again.  But apart from the actual crashes, the technical imperfections and superfluous content don’t hurt the overall experience. With its self-aware silliness, smartly stupid dialogue and plot, and a penchant for operatic destruction, Saint’s Row IV is an excellent way to blow off some steam after a stressful day.  @PopCultJunk

It took me about 35 hours to beat SRIV. Having played all the predecessors, this is a trip down memory lane. From Saints Row to Saints Row The Third, there are flashbacks to various moments in the timeline.  The storyline is straight forward and the side-quests are basic, but it does not deminish the experience any. There are always the generic 'capture' quests that have become a staple of the Saints Row series, but they have added more mini-games this time around including psychic throwing and Pipedream style hacking.  The developers made it easy to collect the various easter eggs especially since there is a 'find treasure' perk available halfway through the game. As a result, this is the first game in a long time that I put forth a conscious effort to complete side tasks secrets because of the in-game unlocks.  The game becomes easier as you level and unlock more perks, but even with the unlocks it is still a rewarding experience with the powers unlocked.  This is a fitting end to the series and resolves most if not all loose ends. Perhaps the biggest disappoint is that it is the conclusion to the story and we may never see this awesome cast again.

When I heard this game was being released I immediately screamed 'HOW!!!! THQ HAVE DIED???' My neighbours were very confused! This game however was produced by a new team of Developers with new Ideals and a chance to step into the fairly hefty shoes of THQ.  Some say that they did not do it. I on the other hand think they did an Admirable job! We are forgetting one thing, The rights were handed over for the Saints Row Franchise, this means that so was the plan for SR4, So people slagging off SR4 because 'It was not made by THQ' Can go and insert their opinion into their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and never play with it again!   I must admit though, this game was fun, and bugged me at the same time, I loved the fact I was not a Super hero with amazing map-travelling abilities and the defiance to blow an entire camp of Alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s into space with a Gun spewing Dubstep which recollects as Pwetty lines on my monitor. And the ability to Shoot waves of fire from my Steampunk clothes whilst following up with an Air pound which destroyed everything within 2 Miles.   The Story of this game was also funny like it should be and also exciting! Making jokes about the modern gaming industry, Classic Gaming Industry, and so much more! Even SR2 Is mentioned in its jumbled fashion. It is very obvious this is a Saints Row game. Its comedic power is still the same as before and the Graphics though remaining the same but in a slightly different light do not downgrade its value. I can tell it is a Saints row game as I run along A space ship with a Character who resembles Natsu from Fairy tail as I ask EVERYONE I pick up on my adventures as President of the U.S.A (By the way you are president, forgot that bit) for violent sex as I giggle at the conversations they have like a 10 year old discovering that ♥♥♥♥♥♥s exist.   Its comedic value taken out of the equation though it holds a dark fact which bugged me to the limit! It was a Direct clone of An SR3 DLC which means it may not be worth your money, but I still recommend it for the story and the general playability, even though there is a mod that adds the direct super powers into SR3, SHUT UP! I'M NOT FIGHTING WITH MYSELF AGAIN!  The Radio choices are really really nice this time round with music to fit all fashions, It even plays everywhere you go as you seem to have no need for the awesome Space cars you come accross, Flying is the new fashion and it is a lot of fun to do so, Your Super jump and Sprint are amazing for manouverability and general fun-having.   So in summary this game is questionable to be bought, Get it if you have money to spare, and won't mind some new features layered above old ones, I give this game an 8/10 But See for yourself!

I really enjoyed Saint Row III and spend a lot of time playing it. It was a good game, it was taking itself way less seriously than GTA, the story was ridiculous (Zombie? Check! Cowboy Mayor? Check! Wrestlers fight with chainsaw? Check!) and kinda full of holes but it felt intended. Hell the characters were joking about how their choice made no sense and that everything looked like a parody.   Now Saint Row IV is a different beast. It does not has the 'we are not taking ourself seriously' atmosphere; everything is in a serious tone but it makes no sense being serious with a story of alien and virtual reality crap. The story is full of hole that are never quite explained and ends up feeling cheap and rushed out. The jokes characters along the path are not funny unless you are stuck in your pre-teen years. It ends up being quite dull.   Now the play mecanics is a bit better. The super power are interesting and add fun to the game. Unfortunately, it also ruins what was a fun part of the game in Saint Row III : the vehicles. Why would I search around trying to steal new vehicles when I can run faster than a car, run higher than a plane and run on water? Car or helicopters are useful in the first 15-30 minutes of the game assuming you found some. But after that you don't care / don't need them. Weirdly enough the missions still reward you with those until very late in the game... Worst, some late mission force you to ride car although you would be better off running. It really feel like the developers didn't think this whole super-power balance through.  The game has some minor bugs, like scene not loading, achievements not being rewarded, some guns offered has reward in two different missions. There is also a certain number of places where I was wondering 'wtf am I suppose to do' as some mecanics or mission really lacks explanations... Overall, the bugs and the lack of explanations are not that bad but it makes me feel the game was rushed and not quite tested.   It feel like the game was just rushed out. They took an old engine, they used the old characters, hell they even took the old city map of Saint Row III. Then they added some aliens, some unconvincing virtual reality crap and they called it a new game. But in the end it really feel like a big DLC. Not even a good one or a funny one.   If you were a fan of the serie, wait until it gets around 5$, this does not worth 22$ at all.  If you are new to the serie... go buy yourself Saint Row The Third. It is the same map, the same engine, the same characters BUT it is funny as hell, well made and it is fun to play.

If you've played Saint's Row The Third, you've played this.

While it has a lot of charm, it is also a mess. Most missions are grinding and repetitive, and combat sequences usually turn into an explosion of particle effects and explosions. Expect to be tossed around as a ragdoll for extended periods when it gets hectic.  I liked SR3 quite a lot but this one should be picked up at a sale, and even so, you'll have to grind through dozens upon dozens of missions so it is a rather large investment, time-wise.

I loved Saints Row III, but finishing IV was hard. Really.  The game is almost exactly like III with a red filter and aliens planted all over it. The humour hasn't changed at all, which I guess isn't only a bad thing. The game looks almost the same and kind of feels the same, so what's the catch?  All the missions felt like replaying everything all over again. All the side quests were just different minigames in a different order, again and again. Fully completing all missions was a pain in the ♥♥♥, not fun at all. Only a few main missions felt exciting and fun to play, since sometimes you actually got to do something new for a change. Everything was just too damn repetitive and messy.  Maybe the worst thing about this game were the superpowers. It can be just me, but I really prefer these GTA-like games with a more 'realistic' touch. Killing enemies wasn't even a challenge anymore and all of the vehicles were just useless. There was no point in using any vehicle when you could just jump around. I liked some of the features, but at times they were either overpowered or making things that made SR3 fun only useless. For example Insurance Fraud used to be fun as hell, but now it was just pressing one button and waiting.  Even though I really shouldn't say that Saints Row's plot is the most important thing I guess we all can say that now it made even less sense than before - and only in a weird way. All the aliens and the paraller world things just felt lame. Everything that made SR3 so fun and 'random' was pushed even further to create something really unimaginative. But I guess it just wasn't my cup of tea. So maybe the problem just was that the game was more like a huge DLC than a full game.  Also this may be the buggiest game I've seen for a while. Some achievements don't come at all even if all of the requirements have been fulfilled and in multiplayer the other player keeps disconnecting multiple times when playing an instance. Everything keeps teleporting and enemies may fall through floors etc. It wouldn't be a problem if it didn't happen all the time.  I don't see any replay value or anything that could keep me playing longer than the main story lasts. :D Except for the ice cream gun. And finding clusters. I really could just play SR3 and forget about this one.

Came in expecting an extention of Saints Row: The Third.  What I got was a game that was insanely easy except for the absolute final boss, which was made a little easier with a little stroke of luck and a glitch. There's a LOT of glitches in this game that I experienced, such as broken/breaking AI, Teleportation, Immortality of enemies, and enemies/homies glitching through the floor. I never really saw a need to use super powers aside from Ice Blast, aside from the forced sections (Genki's M.O.M., Cluster collection, scripted events), as they were rather lackluster and overall not very useful (Telekenesis was very hard to use, Stomp had a HUGE delay with a tiny effective radius, and Buff just never really came up as necessary).  The humor was still very tongue-in-cheek, but there's a lot of gags that require you to have knowledge of Saints Row 2 & 3 in order for you to understand properly. I haven't played through Saints Row 2, so I don't know the exact instances of Veteran Child and the rest of the Vice Kings, but I did get enough from this game to get the general jist of things for what was needed.  Overall, I paid 20$ for a game that honestly felt rushed and unpolished. It's incredibly easy, the Heavy SMG just tears through enemies like butter, and overall I don't feel like it's justified of even a bargin-bin 10$ price if it ever were to go that low. Pass on this unless you get it on the cheap.

From my experience...   Saints Row IV - Fun but Lame, at the same time....   Saints Row IV is the latest game in the Saints Row franchise and it compared to the previous games it goes BATS#@T CRAZY.   Pros:   +Starring: God's Perfect Idiot (The President of the United States of America), ALIENS and an Awesome Crew   +Good Customization, especially the 'Personality' option - really cool and funny.  +Very Good Writing, I honestly laughed at the stupidity and jokes of the characters.  +Great Characters (Johnny Gat and Ben 'Motherf@cking' King are just awesome).  +Level Design is really good, the developers have done a really good job at creating different simulations for each crew member (some showing moments from the previous games).   +Awesome soundtrack to satisfy all tastes, you can create your own playlist in-game or just play your own music playlist from Spotify, Steam Music, etc.  +Zinyak is a witty and comedic villain but much like Handsome Jack from the 'Borderlands' series is a voice that tries to get under your skin and ends with a sort of satisfactory Final Boss fight.   +Superpowers (but they are also in the 'Cons' section).   +Driving is okay-ish.   +You can complete this game with a buddy in co-op.   +Audio Logs and the return of some characters from the previous games like Mini-Bosses.  Cons:   -For a game this ambitious it is really short (8-9 hours).  -EXTREMELY REPETITIVE Side Quests, Just the crew member that gives you the quests is different.   -Cluster Collecting feels like a chore, honestly.  -Superpowers are given waaaaay too early in the game, this kills the reason for the player to even bother getting a car, let alone customize it.  -The 'Romance' option, I honestly believe it was put for comedy value, needless to say that the cutscenes are always the same everytime you want to get laid (but I have to say the dialogue is pretty funny).  -Some powers feel useless and not fun to play with (Buff, Force Shield).  -The mini-games are honestly boring and uninspired (Except 'Fraud').     Overall: 7/10 If you want a fun time with a friend of just a few laughs, go ahead and buy BUT I do not recommend buying it at full price, at a sale for 5 Euros wouldn't be a 'bad' purchase.

Ok, half the game done, time to write a review. To be short, it's a cheap game. Not in terms of price, but in terms of development. Firstly, it's not a sequel, it's an expansion pack. And a pretty boring one — the city is redesigned, a couple mission types added, also there are superpowers now, but mostly we saw all the same stuff in Saints Row The Third. The fourth installment of the series also lacks good story and, most importantly, there's not so much cutscenes. Even the videogame and other nerd-culture references are not helping. Yes, this is one of the games which can be funny to play co-op drinking beer and chatting through Skype, but that does not make this game a good one. In fact, if you are single-playering this — Saints Row IV gets boring very, very quick. I liked the third Saints Row game better, mostly because it offered a decent story with lots of cutscenes and nice characters. Here — not so good.  4/10

Very short for an open world game: 94% completion in under 30 hours.   Graphics are largely disappointing even on max settings:  Extremely poor texture quality. There's writing on stuff, but you won't be able to make it out do the the compression.  Low polygon count on objects. The pool balls are angular instead of round.  The pop-in distance for vehicles, pedestrians, etc. is very small.  Large parts of the game feel out of place. The way the aliens are referred to as a gang, vehicle customization but with zero need to use a vehicle (you run faster than anything in the game), homies (despite you being extremely overpowered), etc.  This game feels like a DLC that was stretched beyond its limits, and not like a polished standalone title.  There are some definite fun moments, and the humor is there. If you're the type of person who plays games with god mode and unlimited ammo on the entire time, and still has fun, then you'll probably like this. Otherwise I would suggest waiting until it is on deep discount.

This game, while has a nice idea and ticks a lot of boxes for a great game, falls flat on some of the more terrible, game breaking bugs.  First of all, while doing a mission, sometimes enemies don't spawn or the NPC that you have to escort is not moving. In a challenge called Speed Rift, sometimes it is possible to lose control while running and you end up being stuck in a wall. Now this is nothing that happened only to me, I've googled these things and it appears that a lot of other people find these bugs frustrating. And the fact that Volition had so much time to fix all that and still didn't do so, is even worse.  The game is funny with over the top action, jokes, references to other games, movies or iconic characters like Metal Gear, Splinter Cell, Star Wars, Star Trek, Martian Manhunter. Also a great addition is Nolan North's voice that you can choose for your character and it feels like you're playing Deadpool at times (I guess Activision thought that it was a great idea to give whatever scraps of the voice material they didn't need for the Deadpool game).  The problem is, the side missions are mostly people asking you to do challenges, which if I wanted to do, I wouldn't play a mission in the first place. It's kind of rushed, unlike the previous games, which is sad, because parts of the game are really well done.  All in all, if you can handle the bugs and repetitive missions and want an over the top action game where you can play a super hero, then by all means, get the game (you can get the game cheaper than the original price, so I'd suggest that), otherwise, a good decision would be not to buy the game, obviously.

I'd even say JC2 looks prettier too.  Volition return pretty much the same game as Saints Row: The Third, now this time has more crippling bugs. We've got random crashes and restarts, the usual slow downs that were in The Third (Still not fixed - awesome). Made the game a little bit better looking, and added a few annoying as hell bugs. The actual game when it is working isn't half bad. Lacking the lulz from previous games, and little to no imagination with the story. The story is pretty much every sci-fi cliche in the last 20 years. Perhaps a bit more parody instead of just blatantly ripping off every other good idea that has already come before it would have worked better than shoving it all in and hoping it fits.
This game is pretty solid, but they take it way too seriously. All it is is dramatic moments and serious plot twists. The writers need to learn to live a little.

After finishing both Saints Row 2,3,and 4, I do believe my journey with Dahlia (my Boss/President) is complete. I am giving this game a thumbs up with some caveats.  1. The Story DLCs feel malnourished. the Christmas one was fun. But Enter the Dominatrix feels like 'an alternate ending' to Saints Row: The Third. Even though production was hampered while Volition/Saints Row was sold to DeepSilver, the ETD DLC feels like scribbly notes in the dev's notebooks, with voiceovers by the cast. It feels... unfinished.  2. Since SR:TT, Saints Row has shifted gears. Not a bad thing, I'm down with that. But The newer games don't seem to have the level of interaction that SR2 had. SR4 attempts to remedy this with new races and tons more activities, but I miss racing cars and buying a 40oz, hopping into a septic truck and lowering some property values. HOWEVER, they still maintain that they are fun. Which they ARE. Which is important, right?  3.Inexplicable things and untouched-upon past events. The crew tend to jabber about past events like they were yesterday but never mention specifics. What happened in Salt Lake City? What happened when the President and that reporter were caught in that room? None of it is explained/expanded upon, and it feels less like characters interacting and more like just a way to lead-in to the random task that the crew is asking you to do. Just a thought.  Overall, the game is, at it's core, fun. Which is the whole point of playing games, right?

If you are interested in this game, I strongly suggest purchasing Saints Row the Third in place of Saints Row IV.  The scenario behind SR IV involves an alien race kidnapping you, and placing you in a virtual world that is almost identical to the island layout of Saints Row the Third. The weapon and vehicle customizations are almost identical to those in Saints Row the Third. The games plays out in a similar fashion to that of Saints Row the Third.  Where Saints Row IV goes wrong is by adding a 'superpower' skill deck that nullifies the need for vehicles and guns. Therefore, not only is the game long-winded in the development of its storyline, but your progress is essentially wiped clean once your super-skills reach a certain threshold: it becomes a game about a wandering Spiderman/Superman hybrid that breaks all the in-game rules to move through the tenuous, shallow storyline.  TL;DR: SR IV shatters too many illusions, and breaks too many rules to be more than a tedious sandbox playground.

You know, I really want to thumbs up this game because I love the SR series...but I just can't. While I did enjoy the game to a certain extent, it felt...I dunno, depressing, redundant, and not satisfying? Welcome to Steelport...again. Its the same city as last time (which is close to half the size as Stilwater), and most of the fun is gone. Remember all those diverse soundtracks and entertaining news clips you heard in vehicles? Well, you're not going to get much this time around, because you'll find you use your super running powers rather than car jack in this game because you're faster and have better control. Guns? Sure, you'll use them to supplement your blasty powers but they are fairly lackluster too. Many reviewers have said that this game feels more like an expansion for SRIII than a new game, and I have to agree with them.   Ultimately its a Saints Row game in 'The Matrix'. Is it a bad game? No...I guess not, but it will probably remain the black sheep of the series if more are made. Frankly, without spoiling the story or ending beyond what they tell you in the summary, a much more fun and better idea for gameplay mechanics are revealed at the ending of the game as a story element. So, based on the ending credits let's hope there is a SR5 because it could be quite fun.

Welcome to the Hype train. What could have been a good game, sadly is not. The game itself trys most of the time way to hard to be funny when it simply isnt. After 20+ Hours i just wanted the game to end as fast as possible. The Mainstory is nothing special but i dont want to spoil too much. Side missions are repetetive and have no innovation whatsoever. Go there, defent that, kill X enemies, run/drive trough a specific course; the usual stuff by the dozens. You grow tired of them in no time.  Graphics are okayish, but definetly not great for the time of its release. Animations seem stiff. Controlls are also not that good if you want to play it with your keyboard & mouse. Probably ok with gamepad I guess. The AI ist just stupid as hell. Buddys in sidemissions will die regularly because they are either in the mood for suicide by charging in every enemy horde they see or are just standing there doing absolutely nothing. For example I had to repeat many missions because some braindamaged npc didnt feel like getting in the car next to him but instead tried to punsh the ♥♥♥♥ out of a tank.   Its also buggy as hell. While playing the main story, some video sequences in co-op mode crashed every time while loading so we were force to skip them. That alone wouldnt be so bad if you werent also forced to play the whole level again since the game only saves after said video sequences. Since you dont know which sequences will crash and which wont while you are in your first playthrough I recommend skipping them all or bring some time and patience. Other features in the game also tend to lag tremendously or sometims just dont work at all until you start buttonsmashing till they do (call car / buddy etc.). Sometimes, they wont even work until you restart the game completely.   Co-op partners also do lose connection kinda often but i dont know if its the games or the steam servers fault. In any case as soon as somebody loses conncetion while in a quest, the quest will be marked als failed for every other player and hast to be restarted. There is no option to rejoin in a quest, and many times non at all until you restart the whole game.    The whole game just feels bulky and unfinished. A year more in development and this game could have been good but at this state, it simply isnt. Its definetly not worth the money its currently priced. Im glad i got it for just around three bucks.

First of all, this game is good, the story is good, it's funny, the gameplay is not that bad and everything.  But this game is full of game breaking bugs despite the devs 'trying to patch them up'. Here's a list of what bugs I encountered:  -Stupid npc dying from stupid physics bug -Player instantly dying from physics bug -Game breaking infinite loading screens (I restarted 3 characters to get past them) -Glitchy cutscenes and animations -Really bad or glitchy script (The mission scripts sucks even more when you're playing coop mode) -Stupid Hard mode, they simply multiplied the damage and didn't test anything, some scripted damage (from cutscene) kill you, wtf ?! -Awful desync when you got a bit too laggy -When you get out of the simulation you got stuck in cutscene mode and became unable to do anything except opening the pause menu. The only way to get out is to load the last save you got.  This is only what I encountered, keep in mind that there's a ton more bugs like these, and if you're a bit courageous then buy it, but you've been warned.  I love Saints Row franchise, I love this game, but these bugs are intolerable, even more knowing they'll never fix them. I can't finish this game in coop mode at all because of an infinite loading screen, and when I try to bypass it by restarting the mission (By making the other player disconnect and reconnect, it make it past the loading screen for some reasons) I got unable to move or do anything except the pause menu.  I can't say this is a good game because of all these bug. Don't buy it, except if you like to break a lot of keyboard in an unending rage.

One of the best open-world sandbox action RPG TPS superhero gang-land cyperpunk games ever made. Seriously. The amount of customization, replay-value, unlockables, easter eggs, and just outright fun in this game is pretty much unmatched. I'd have to rank this up there with Just Cause 2, Saints Row 2 and classic 3D-era GTA as some of the absolute Jesus-tier sandbox games out there. And the fact that you can literally go from 0% to 100% all in co-op with a friend just makes it 100x better.   Smooth, stylistic graphics? Yep.  Fun, varied mission selection? Yep.  Tight, fluid controls? Yep. Well-optimized for PC? Yep.  Insane level of customization? Yep.  Awesome dialogue and story? Yep.  Fantastic co-op implementation? Yep.  Fun and addictive gameplay? Yep.  Nice music collection? Yep.   I just don't even know. Look at the reception on Steam, it says it all. If I had to name a few gripes, it's that the game didn't balance the time it takes to unlock the powers as well as they could've (you sorta get them a little too quick) and this makes one element of the game (driving vehicles) completely redundant and unnecessary, but you'll soon get over it once you see how fun it is to super-jump and glide across the city with ease.   Currently SR2 is still my favorite in the series, but it's a shame that the PC port was horrible because it was done by an external studio and they ♥♥♥♥ed it all up. Good thing I played it mainly on PS3. But this game is still a more-than-worthy entry in the series and righted many of the wrongs brought forth by the terrible story from the third game. If you think fun is good, buy this game, that's all there is to it.

TL;DR: Good Co-op, good progression, fun activities, good story, Super powers. Overall 8.5/10  What can i possibly say about this game? Well first of all, before i actually played the game i thought it was stupid how the game added super powers to Saints Row, I had played SR: The Third and was completely aware about the shenanigans that would come with SR4 but that's just one thing i didn't really like about the game. Another reason i wasn't interested in SR4 was due to the ending of SR3. When i had purchased SR4 i had went into the game with very low expectations and you'll get to see my opinion on the game.  First of all let me start with this --> You're the president of the US *The president of the United Saints* which is pretty badass.  The plot is introduced in the first few missions which compared to the other SR games i didn't really like but hey I bought this game because i'm bored of GTA this game is in no way comparable to any of the GTA games.  After revealing the plot all the things i didn't like about the game seemed to vanish, since you don't actually live in the real city of Steelport you're living in a simulation of Steelport made by the alien bad guy antagonist, which really makes me feel better about the whole idea of superpowers.   The comedy in the game is pretty hilarious, it's much better than the SR3 comedy was, it's got a lot of moments that really make me laugh.   Since i'm me there is one selling point on the game and that is: Upgrades and character progression. All of your guns have things to upgrade such as explosive ammo, fire rate, damage, recoil, RoF, it's all really cool, The penetrator remains in the game which deep down makes me happy knowing i can run around Steelport F*ing people in the face with my giant ♥♥♥♥♥ bat. Cars can also be upgraded and pimped out in the same way as previous SR games, although the reliance on vehicles is much lower due to the first two super powers you get. As you play through the game you can collect Data Clusters which allow you to upgrade your super powers, although they don't require much searching they're still really cool to collect and upgrade your powers with. And lastly you can upgrade you character himself/herself in the same way you did in SR3 collect Cache *money* and level up via missions and activities to unlock new upgrades.  Co-Op for once in a SR game Co-op is a key point to the game, without playing co-op it's impossible to achieve 100% game completion. If you're anti-social and hate people it's not the game for you. But, if you've got a friend to play it with it'll be one of the best game purchases you can make.   Overall the game is pretty damn good i'd give it a solid 8.5/10 So far i don't have many complaints it's a really good game. Grab a friend and rip through the Co-op. The game is totally worth the 20$

I bought Saints Row 2, Saints Row the Third, and Saints Row IV all at the same time when they were on sale, and played them in order. Saints Row IV is easily my favorite of the three, despite bringing back SRtT's slightly limited character customization and the terribly designed city of Steelport (deliberately ♥♥♥♥♥♥ city-planning is still ♥♥♥♥♥♥ city-planning).   Fortunately, very early in the game you obtain super powers, and the joy and rush of power from being able to sprint faster than you can drive and leaping over buildings allowed me to quickly look past those shortcomings. The ability to access the in-game radio stations even when not in a vehicle is a nice touch as well (and necessary, as you probably won't bother with conventional automobiles, boats, or planes).  I also appreciate that this game managed to balance out Shaundi's personality. The shift from mostly useless stoner in SR2 to hardass ♥♥♥♥♥ in SRtT (who, ironically, was kidnapped more times in that game) swings back to more of a middle ground in IV when she literally comes face to face with herself. Her character arc feels as though the writers are specifically attempting to address complaints about how she was written in the past.   A potential negative to players who haven't experienced the previous installments is that the Saints Row series is loaded with callbacks and has a high degree of continuity from game to game that isn't explained. SRIV does do a little better about this than previous games, as the personal hell simulations the player has to rescue their crew from are essentially flashbacks to previous events, and one type of collectibles in this game are audio logs filling in backstory and character insight.  I've seen a lot of complaints that the increasing ridiculousness of the franchise is a betrayal of its gritty roots, but I prefer the growing absurdity and sense of fun that Saints Row IV embraces rather than a game like Saints Row 2, which might be described as 'like GTA, but... with funny outfits, I guess.'

Quick review:   The Good   -Fun and varied gameplay that offers a surprising level of challenge, from open world sandbox to bizarre parodies to high-speed superpowered races -Co-op offers plenty of extra mayhem -Lots of character customization, including new ways to customize guns -Enjoyable story and characters -Plenty of wacky and [im]mature humor -Lots of subtle fanservice for those who have played previous Saints Row games -Good length (20+ hours)   The Bad   -Game feels rushed towards ending and is rough around the edges in other places (like subtitles not matching what is being said) -Side missions and collectibles are required for many upgrades and become tedious after a while -Almost identical to SR3 in many respects, including customization items; seems less of a new game and more of an expansion pack -Lack of graphical improvement over SR3 -Vehicles and followers are way less useful than in previous games to the point where it seems intentional -Low replay value unless one wants to play again on a higher difficulty or with a friend   Other   The weirdest pacing for a game you will ever experience. When does the 'real' game begin? When does it end? You'll be guessing for a while. And just try explaining what kind of game this is to a friend. 'Gangster game where you are the President of the United States fighting aliens' only begins to scratch the surface.  Overall: 8.5/10, a good and fun experience that will produce more than a few laughs.  Newcomers to the series should play previous games before this one.

I dressed up as a fat naked Santa and probed an alien 10/10  Now for the serious review:  I'll just start out with this: buy this game. It is incredible amounts of fun.   --Seriousness-- Fans of Saints Row 2 have critized this game a lot for not being a true gangster game anymore. I,as a fan of Saints Row 2 and disliker of Saints Row 3,disagree. Yes,it's completely mental,but that's what makes it fun. A true gangster SR game would've been critized for being a Grand Theft Auto rip-off,even if it wasn't. And it would need to compete with GTA,which SR frankly can't win. The obvious choice here was to distance themselves from realism and play around with superpowers and aliens. Yeah,you read that right. You become the president of the USA,you get abducted by aliens and you get thrown into a simulation where you get superpowers. And it works.  --Story-- I'll keep it short,because I don't want to spoil anything. It somehow still has dramatic moments. It also has extremely funny moments. All in all,a suprisingly good story.  Now for just the Pros and Cons:  --PROS-- +Superpowers. They work great,are not that overpowered and are extremely fun. +Progression. You can level up and spend your cash on player upgrades,or find ''orbs'' and spend those on superpower upgrades. And the end of the game,you really feel like you've accomplished something. +Customization. Although many people think the vehicles are now useless because of the superpoweres,customizing them is even more fun now. You can also upgrade weapons,and the charachter creator and clothes selection are sublime as ever. +Humor. This game is really funny. That's all i'm going to say. +Co-op. Playing this game with 2 people is even more fun than playing on your own.  +Fun factor. This game doesn't forget what games are about: fun. Realism is thrown out the window for pure fun. And believe me,this game is a LOT of fun.  --CONS-- -Vehicles. Many people believe vehicles are now useless. They are,don't get me wrong,but I still like driving them around. Still,they are pretty useless. -Not gangster. I personally don't think this is a con,but i'll include it because plenty of people think it is.   --CONCLUSION-- Completely insane amounts of fun. If you don't mind unrealistic games,this is a must-buy.

Don't get me wrong. Saints Row IV is fun. I really enjoy jumping around, the puzzles, and the awesome and humorous dialogues from previous games. It's a great time.  However, you don't kill a single human being in the entire game. Yep, you heard that right. My gleeful sociopath didn't kill one human. The whole game takes place in a simulation where nothing is real. I mean, it's not real anyway, but at least it's not usually fake *in the game*. What's the point of being a god-like gangster if I can't accidentally kill a few civilians?  Also, the complete reuse of Steelport actually makes the game feel kind of unfinished. It's almost more like an expansion or a very big DLC than a standalone game. Most of my time is spent in the same area as in Saints Row: The Third, which is still the best of the series. Sure, superpowers let me see it from a new perspective, but it's kind of strange to play in exactly the same areas as in the last game.  SRIV has the same port problems as SR3. It's slow, even on a very good computer, and recommends the highest settings when it lags on anything short of low. Many people complain about this, and I can play much better games on my computer without a hitch. It's too bad, because the game looks pretty good most of the time.  Adding loyalty missions to go with the open-world missions actually brings a nice structure to it. Plus, adding bronze-silver-gold gives new options to shoot for without compromising success in the loyalty missions. It's the one advantage it has over SR3.  So, basically, a very good game. I loved it, played every mission, and then never touched it again. It's worth the price.  Score: 8/10

<might contain spoilers> I liked this game because it is similar (in gameplay) to GTA, but it has a unique perspective, in being funnier and more dettached to reality. You play as the President of the USA, when an alien invasion occurs. Your job is to kill the aliens and avenge Earth. Yes, I said avenge, not save. Lots of humans were abducted and are now enslaved, with their minds connected to a computer simulation of Earth, much like The Matrix. So you, as the President, will spend most of the time in this simulation, where you will acquire superpowers while fighting the aliens in their tron-like vehicles. So... it´s a GTA-like game, with a Matrix plot, and pieces of Tron visual? Yes, exactly! Awesome, heh? And the soundtrack is also awesome. You don´t have to be inside a car to listen to it. To walk in the city with that huge alien mothership in the skyline, listening to a soundtrack like a end of the world party, it´s a pretty cool experience.

Speaking as someone who has only played 'Saint's Row the Third' and this one, I can safely say this is one of the best games I have ever played.   It is such an enjoyable experience there is no person I would not reccomend this to. Coming off 'Saint's Row the Third', I was enjoying my time with the franchise, but it didn't stand out to an amazing degree, but this game took everything I hated about 3, fixed it, and added in all new things to enjoy.    So why is it so good?   Well, I'll start with the central combat mechanics, which I would say are overall better than in 3, with a ton more weapon variety, including all sorts of crazy and amazingly fun weapons, including the Dubstep Gun and the Black Hole Launcher (My personal favorite!), though alot of the more ordinary guns feel alot weaker than in 3. For example, the Alien SMG felt more like it was firing air powered brussel sprouts than laser shots. Also, I feel the weapon balance is a bit off. Though it may be really fun, and I definately prefer it to the alternative, from a technical standpoint, I shoud not be able to one shot with a completely unimproved melee weapon, recovering all lost health from a pickup he drops. Later on, I would clear entire flashpoints with nothing but a tentacle bat or a laser sword. Combat also includes the brand new superpowers, which are mostly really fun to play around with, and can do some real damage. However, I think alot of powers are either useless, or made obsolete by other powers. Why would I shoot a fireball at one enemy when I can surround myself in a temporary aura of fire, burning all nearby enemies as I get them well acquainted with my tentacle?  Alot of people point at the character customization in 2 as being incredible, and say they were dissappointed in customization in 3 and 4. Having very briefly played 2, I can say there is such a thing as too much detail, and that has it. 4 has plenty of choices to make whatever character you want, including different voices with different dialogue, though I found the developers really didn't put a whole lot of effort into the voices other then Male Voice 1 and maybe Male Voice 2, since, in my first playthrough as Female Voice 1, the subtitles constantly said something different to my character, which is a minor complaint, but it really annoyed me. Another complaint is they didn't seem to build on the wardrobe from 3, and rather replaced it, so alot of clothes I liked from before are gone, in favor of four of the same fedora with a slightly different rim.   Until I heard complaints about it and actually took a good look at the map, I couldn't even tell it was Steelport again. The jump and sprint powers make travel so much fun for awhile, though it did eventually become routine, and that verticality to moving on foot makes it feel like a different city, at least to me. However, that hits upon one of my main complaints: cars. In 3, cars were vital, and in 4, they added tons of new cars, most of which are incredibly interesting and funny in concept and execution. There's a ♥♥♥♥ing man-a-pult, for God's sake! However, I was almost never tempted to use vehicles of any kind, since traveling on foot was so much faster and more efficient, which is a real shame, because vehicles seem so interesting. The problem is really exemplified whenever a mission requires you drive around and you realize how much you want to get out, jump into the air, and dive nuke a city block.    *YOU MAY FIND SPOILERS IN THIS PARAGRAPH*   The story is honestly pretty shallow in its broad concept. Break the simulation by doing activities while rescuing your crew. It's a means to an end, but alot of the individual missions, particularly the rescue missions are very fun, though many of the normal missions are very very repetitive and even kind of 'grindy', you could say, which is one of the biggest criticisms of the game by most. But all these missions present a bonding experience to get you to care about each and every character, and that's really the games strongest point: the characters. I absolutely love every character in this game. They are all well defined, and the game lets you spend casual bonding time with each one to make you actually enjoy having them around, not to mention every one is enjoyable in their own way. I'd imagine this would be rapidly trumped in a story-focused game, but as someone who hasn't been exposed much to those, one of my favorite character moments came in this game, and it was when Pierce and the Boss start singing along to the radio during a mission. The dialogue, humor, and sense of absolute careless fun from the voice actors makes it a scene with not much depth, but just a flat out good time, a scene that just makes you feel happy and invested, which is really what games are about, right? And the ending. I ended up getting the good ending first time, and it is such a good ending. No poetic depth, no thought-provoking parting message, no final riddle, but just a good, light-hearted ending that made you feel accomplished and all warm inside, seeing the characters have just a good a time as you.  Switching over to the other main strength, let's talk about the humor. This game is filled with absolutely hillarious moments. One big complaint I have about 3 is it really just has one joke: ♥♥♥♥♥, BUMS, ♥♥♥♥, SEX, GET IT, IT'S FUNNY RIGHT?, which can be good when done right and in moderation, but was seriously overdone. This game has references, parodies, that oh so random humor that's fun when done right, which it is here, original dialogue humor, and it still retains that dirty humor from 3, but in a much better balance with the rest of it to make those jokes consistently funny. The dialogue is amazing, and I willingly listened to all of it and wanted more just because it was so good.  In conclusion, I highly reccomend this game. Sure there are some goods and bads I left out, but I think this covers the important points, at least in my experiences. It had plenty of flaws and missed alot of potential in alot of its elements, but the action, powers, characters, and humor in this game, combined with an obvious sense of absolute dedication to fun has this game stand out as being superb, and I truly cannot understand how people would rather have some dark and serious 'Grand Theft Auto' clone over this gem.

*THERE WILL BE MAJOR SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED* A great game with absolutely hilarious diaglogue and a very enjoyable story. Meeting all your old faviroute characters from previous saints row titles is a real blast from the past.  Advantages: -The game runs smoothly and looks very pretty -The diaglogue is hilarious and the writing is fantastic -The story is enjoyabe and with enough comedy to make it hilarious, but not too much to make it seem like it's trying too hard -A very diverse set of powers, upgrades and very fun progression. -JONNY GAT IS ALIVE  Disadvantages: -The map is more-or-less the same as SR3 with very few changes -Once the game is complete, you cannot get rid of the alien structures so if you don't like them sucks to be you -You cannot get rid of upgrades or toggle them on or off so if you want to run around normaly after you have super sprint, you can't   Overall, SR4 can feel like you're playing SR3 again as superman, but it is still a great game with over the top action sequences, hilarious diaglogue unmatched by any other comedy game and a huge open world which you are free to explore (or destroy) at your leisure. 9/10

This review comes from someone who has played Saints Row 3 and loved it very much. The reasons why I gave this game a negative review are as follows : 1) The concept of 'Aliens attack the earth' feels very generic. 2) Though you have a wide variety of super powers to play around with most of them like ice blast and fire are nothing new.  3) Most of the Main Quests take place 'OUTSIDE' of Steelport city/Simulation. The city is just there for you to play around with your superpowers on your own and completing the rinse and repeat side quests. 4) Talking about side quests they go like : ' Meet .... on the ship'   - Disrupt the system  - Race throught the system  - Clear out the zin troops  - Inject virus  ' Meet ....... to get your reward'   This goes on and on until they think they had enough of you. The same objectives over and over and over again.And you need to complete them to unlock powers and weapons. Did I ever tell you the definition of insanity.  5) All your homies refer to you as 'Boss' and make you work like a slave in the side quests above. This game badly suffers from 'You are the only one who is competent' cliche. 6) The tough decisions that we need to do at the end of some Major Quests in SR3 are no more there. The text adventure section of SR3 is replaced by a more boring and stupid one, in one of the missons.  Overall, this game may seem fun if you watch the videos. The superpowers may look cool at first. But the novelty wears off very soon as you don't get to use in them in the Main Quests. The only place where they are actually used are in the boring and repetitive side quests and when you are on your own.
