Obtaining Saints Row 4 without Steam in my Country (Germany) is pretty much asking for a quick execution of yourself, because it's been censored quite a bit and pretty difficult to get if you don't have something like GameStop in the area. However, i managed to get it now through Steam and playing it, soon i realized that this censoring kind of had a point. If the game wasn't censored like this, it might encourage people to do some insane irresponsible stuff, like shooting fire from their hands, jumping 40 meters into the air or  going into politics .  After he (or, in your backward-Universe, she) saves the world from terrorists, the leader of the 3rd Street Saints becomes the president of the United States and starts running the country into the ground so hard that it tunnels through and ends up under China. Then Aliens attack, kidnap you and seal you into a computer simulation of Steelport from Saints Row 3. Very kind of the Aliens to spare the Developers the task of designing a new Sandbox! But it is actually okay, because the game uses the old Sandbox for new Gameplay elements along the lines of Prototype, complete with the ability to make a dive, face front, into a tank and destroying it - along with pretty much everything in the general area.  Whereas the first Saints Row games were silly, but still grounded in some realism, like Saints Row 2 was, Saints Row 4's relationship with Realism is a quick farewell-kiss before drinking drug-infused Fanta out of a clown's shoe and skyrocketing onto the backside of Mars. Within the first half hour, Saints Row 4 managed to parody Call of Duty, Armageddon, Independence Day, The Matrix and Space Invaders without a single breather. But it's still more grounded than Saints Row 3 was. No, seriously, i mean it! Saints Row 3 was always going up and down between Saints Row 2's 'silly crime Sandbox' and Saints Row 4's 'bats**t-s**tting-bats-crazy drug trip', and as such it couldn't quite decide on a tone it wants to have.  Saints Row 4 now has accomplished the Task that began with Saints Row 2, which is cleaning off the dirt that marked the Saints Row games as a „Subpar GTA Knockoff“. However it is weird that the Game reminisces so much about the stuff we've finally gotten rid of, with characters from each previous Saints Row game. However, the „Subpar GTA Knockoff“ is now completely rinsed off from this game, which now reveals the game's wacky comedy, which can only be judged by whether the game made me laugh or not. Well, it generally made me laugh, simply because of the fun you have by beating people up with an oversized wobbling sex toy, and the dialogue between the characters is, as always, hilarious to listen to, and some of the parodies work. However it does fall flat at times. Entire sections of the game attempt to make fun of popular games nowadays, but fail to understand the difference between a Parody and a Reference, just like Duke Nukem Forever. One brief chapter is entirely devoted to mock Metal Gear Solid, complete with a cardboard box, inside which you hide to then take out guards from behind, but that's not a joke! It's just what you do in Metal Gear Solid. If you mock through imitation, at least put on a silly face while doing so, or, even better, kick them between the legs!  Saints Row 4 also gets a fair share of licensed music! The Prologue is accompanied by that one Aerosmith song from the Armageddon soundtrack, that just about everyone tearfully admits is kind of alright, and there are other examples, usually to positive effect, but i eventually relaized that they only did this because they made a Sandbox with cars and Radio stations, only to figure out that there's no reason whatsoever to use cars. But even this was cleverly solved by having the radio always available, vehicle or not.  The Game gives you those Superpowers i talked about earlier right at the start (kind of), and then spends the entire story mode regretting this, because all the story missions have some weird reason for your powers to not work, making you wonder why you even spend upgrades on them. The Final Boss however is a great Superpower-Brawl that rounds things up well. Another thing i really liked is that you can get health back from killing enemies, which keeps the pace up, whereas in previous games all you could do was duck and cover and wait for blood to fall off your face. But for some reason, this power is removed during the Final Boss, so it goes back to hiding and sucking on your thumb.  Overall, the Game has a lot of stuff, a Sandbox with Superpowers and vehicles, wacky comedy, Sci-Fi-action, game parodies, a lot of Gameplay features being thrown in, used once and then thrown away, and character customization that even Skyrim would be jealous at. Taken as a whole, the Game is a complete mess, but as the end of a series that has always been moving to the point of maximum mess it does its job pretty well. It is a mess, but it's also a lot of fun! This is how all Video Game series' should end: A big, massive, over-the-top roast of itself, and of video games in general, exploding into everything the series does best. Salute it, with the wobbliest sex toy you can find!

Threading on the edge of borderline outrageousness and absurdity, SRIV exceeds its just as whacky predecessor while promising the same good ol' fun. To me, the game initially seemed like a re-skinned night-time version of SR3...with aliens. But play further and it turns out there's been plenty of gameplay changes for the better. Missions are now grouped more tidily, challenges make more sense while acitvities and side missions now feel more purposeful. Of course the hallmark of SRIV is the addition of new powers for the Saints. The immense kinds of superpowers you get makes travelling across the, albeit same, city of Steelport so much less of a chore to do. The freedom you get is something possibly unmatched by any other sandbox, well, maybe apart from Just Cause 2. Screw the need for superhero games. Wanna fly like Superman, run like the Flash, stomp like the Hulk? You get it all here. However, that is not to say having all these powers is simply too amazing. Despite the removal of certain... OP skills, enemies are still flat-out easy and it makes me wonder if Volition wanted the game to be this easy. There's also a certain stiffness to the way the animations and AI work in the game, something that might leave you with a feeling of reptitiveness in playtime eventually.  At its best, it's the story missions of the game that makes up for the worth. The overall premise of the game starts about your Saint being president, though this event is very short-lived, when alien baddies attack, the White House gets blown up and you become a nobody again. What's shown in the game promos can be a little misleading because of this; being the president for about the first five minutes of the game? Yeah..that's about it.  The rest of the game pits you against Zinyak and friends in a struggle to save humanity from them evil do-ers. To do that, you'll have to rescue back the Saints, making them crew members on your ship, where you can talk to them...and romance them. Sounds familiar? Clearly seems like the devs intended this to be a mocking yet a splitting rip-off from the Mass Effect series. On the surface, that's what it is. But the playthrough itself is entirely different. You'll go through the craziest adventures including 2D retro beat-em-ups, battle a giant soda can called Paul and jump back and forth into different dimensions like a recreation of the 1950s. It's hard to take it seriously, and sometimes you might even forget what the f**** the story is supposed to be. So despite some of its shortcomings, I guess it's the main missions that's what truly carries SRIV to the front.

The first Saints Row game was nothing more than a cheap knock off, I liked the 80's metal soundtrack in the game but that was all it had going for it. The second game is when things got entertaining, they just started to parodize the whole gang thing a lot more and poke fun at some relevant societal topics. But the third game is when Volition really started to have fun poking fun at how weird the real world was. Saints Row: The Third wasn't only fun to play but the way it poked fun at the reality tv craze, and Stag was obviously a jab at how Bush handled the war on terror, and it was all done in a very National Lampoon way which was amusing. Well Saints Row IV, it merely picks up where they left off in three and takes even mroe jabs at a lot of the absurd things in the US, and it pays homage to so many things from the 80's you'll lose count. There's the level that totally pays homage to They Live and a Christmas Story (briefly), and then there's tons of weapons from 80's classics like Robocop, Aliens, and GI Joe. And the christmas expansion, the first level is basically a re-creation of the old studio lot where they shot Jaws, Gremlins, and numerous other classics. But towards the end when it pays homage to the animated Transformers film, and even uses the Stan Bush song from the film, that was just a golden moment in the game.  But I'm praising the satire and how they paid homage to so many great films and cartoons and not talking about the gameplay. Gameplay wise the game is pretty fun and the super powers the player can use in the viritual world add a whole new level of gameplay to the franchise since in earlier games, the player had to rely on vehicles to get anywhere fast and always rely on guns or grenades, but in the 4th game the player could still go the gun and grenade route or freeze people or turn them into gold or use telekenisis and throw them into the sky. In short, the game allows players to just go crazy when it comes to taking out pedestrians and the aliens. The controls are as smooth as the third game, which I'm thankful for since Saints Row 2 for the PC, the driving controls were just horrible. If one enjoys open world games where they can just go crazy, this game should please them. But I highly recommend getting the Game of the Century version, or at the very least the base game and the christmas expansion pack. While I adore Volition's sense of humor when it comes ot the SR franchise, Enter the Dominatrix gets a little too corny, while the Christmas expansion is hands down a far better expansion pack. I don't recommend playing any of the expansions until after finishing the main game though since the expansions will spoil a few things otherwise.  However, while I think the game is highly entertaining and totally worth dropping 10-20 on, it does have its flaws and they're the same exact flaws the third game had.  1. The game doesn't have the cool drug and booze thing from the second game, I found it highly amusing how the character could get drunk or stoned in the second game and was sad to see them ditch the ability to do that in the third and fourth. To be fair, it could have been because some countries ban games with drug content, like Australia.   2. The really cool interior locations like the mall in Saints Row 2 added a lot of fun to the game, it was a blast to ♥♥♥♥ off the security guards and then just cause tons of trouble. But Saints Row 3 and 4 just don't have any of those types of interior locations, which is a shame.   3. The player can still play in the water in three and four but it doesn't take long to notice the water isn't used by any of the npc's like in the 2nd game. There aren't any npc's jet ski'ing or driving boats or anything like that, the water is just lifeless.   If Saints Row 5 brings back just 1 or 2 of those three things, I'll love it to pieces.

Saint Row IV is overall a great game in my opinion, for me it is equally good as Saints Row 3 but it is definitely more fun. As for my ratings : Gameplay : 10/10 Story : 9/10 Dialogue : 10/10 Missions: 7/10 The superpowers just give it that extra fun compared to Saints Row 3(which i also loved) The game is very fast paced , full of action and whatnot.The dialogue is just amazing, puns all over the place making it feel less stressful than saving the world from an alien invasion would feel like.The openworld part of it is really cool, you being able to explore and collect clusters to further upgrade your powers. The character customization is a really nice feature; you can customize every little thing about your character, the jaw line, the eyes, the overall face shape, body type etc. and even voice.  As for cons, some of the missions seem forced, like they are just fillers, created to make the game longer. As a conclusion, if you are into action-y, really fun, fast paced games, the Saints Row Franchise its for you ( especially Saints Row 4, although i would recommend starting with SR2 , or maybe even SR3)

Played 50+ hours on XBox 360 and 30+ hours on PC  [+] Excellent variety and progression in skill tree. Wildly exciting mechanics are available very early in the game.  [+] Traversal is a breeze. You don't have to yawn your way through lame driving challenges just to get to a specific area.  [+] Well-developed open world with oodles of activities that are worth doing.  [-] Mandatory story missions gate your progress. All of the missions take away your 'super powers', and kill the pacing of the game. Most of the missions are overlong and simplistic (turret missions, stealth action, QTEs, meta-jokey text-based stuff).  [-] Early in the game, doing well means you have to face 'wardens' in one-on-one battles that tend to be really drawn out, due to the cooldown requirements and the short 'damage windows'.  [-] Due to the super powers, most of the game's features are pretty much meaningless. Superspeed running and gliding makes cars useless. Gang help is completely unnecessary, and might make the game TOO easy.

The fourth installment into the Saints Row franchise, the saints are all captured by a mysterious alien race named the Zin and are forced into a simulation for the alien leader Zinyaks own amusement. The gimmick of the fourth game employs a new mechanic into the world of Saints Row, Super Powers such as Super speed, Super jumping, Buffs, ect. New characters such as CID are introduced, and nostalgic characters such as Benjamin are brought back through the simulation, locked away in their own eternal fears. Several unique functions and clever plot devices introduce characters from all of the games, even Johnny Gat is brought back into the story, showing he never did die. This is an extremely addicting game, and I would even say its better than the Prequel.

In addition, if you play the other stories first, you will get attached to the characters. Although some charactersrecieve unfortunate fates:    Oleg and Josh Birk.    But either way,   in my opinion   this game is quite possibly the best Saints Row game, despite what other say. The most entertaining and funny game of 2013. It's not perfect, it's not a substitute for GTA nor is it for Saints Row even. But I guarantee you that this will please fans of the previous games and newcomers.  It has great flashback episodes to previous Saints Row games, which are big highlights of the game, and the return of familiar characters.  The soundtrack is really sweet and is especially fantastic in the final missions. That finale raises the hair on my neck of just how awesome it really is.  One of the strongest suits the game has is just how funny the writing is. I've never played a game before which made me laugh this much since Conkers Bad Fur Day. But beware, there's tons of referential humor, and I suggest seeing the movie They Live before finishing the game or even before playing it. There are many many more movies to see to understand the rest of the jokes, but They Live is probably the most important.  I can go on and on about how fun this game was and how free and awesome you feel while playing it. It's worth it.  Get the Christmas DLC while you're at it, as it is also hilarious, although a bit short.

You need to play Saints Row 3 before this, and you probably shouldn't pay close to original retail for Saints Row 4.  Saints Row 3 was a phenomenal open world experience. Neither 3 nor 4 struck me as especially difficult. 3 more than made up for it in fun. I enjoyed 4, but it just wasn't the same. Part of what makes 3 so enjoyable is that you're still connected to the open world genre mainstays like the GTA series -- you're doing crazy versions of street crime and working your way up the ladder. Saints Row 3 is really an amazing entry into that genre.  In 4, you very quickly become so overpowered that all the core concepts fall apart. You're not climbing the street crime ladder, and the replacement concept doesn't logically explain why the game would unfold gradually. Battles are extremely formulaic and repetitive without being fun or new or difficult. You end up bypassing all battles you don't have to fight because they are just boring.  The much hyped special gun was a massive letdown for me. Like most of the novelty guns, you use it a couple times for fun, then you've really seen everything there is to see.  That said, I enjoyed the game. I pre-ordered it at full retail based purely on how much I enjoyed SR3. I don't regret that, but I stick by my recommendation: get Saints Row 3 instead of this, then make a decision on how much you're willing to wager on whether you'll enjoy SR4.

This is more SR 3.5 than SR4, but this does not mean it's not a good game. Bear in mind that if you did not like SR3 there is nothing here that would change your mind. If, on the other hand, you liked all the crazy s**t you were doing in Steelport then this is a must buy. Well yes, the Earth was destroyed which is a kind of a bummer, but this doesn't mean the Saints are gonna give up, right? Welcome to the Matrix. Nobody can tell you what the Matrix is, you have to see it for yourself. It does look a lot like your basic Steelport though. And the Saints are back, this time with superpowers! And alien technology weapons! Dubstep gun FTW! Everything that was in SR3 is here, just more.  But just so you know not everything is so peachy. The gfx is just like SR3, doesn't bother me, but it has to be noted. Some game mechanics are obsolete. The whole garage and vehicle driving thing will be skipped due to superpowers being superior to driving 99% of the time. Also, the game is shorter than the predecessor, if you want to do every side mission you should be at around 20hrs.  Best moment... Haddaway playing while I was furiously dodging aliens that tried to fry my ship. Definetely worth the admission price :p

SR IV offers more the same hilarity that makes the whole franchise great. Core gameplay, activities and quests are largely unchanged, spoofing trends in gaming, popular movies, and even its previous iterations. A slew of new and interesting weapons are offered, but you will probably stick with a few OP favourites. Similarly, your characters new super-powers are progressively unlocked through the game, but there are a few classics that you will likely rely on. While Steelport is the same, the ability matrix-esque ability jump and fly gives you a different angle on familiar locales. Voice acting and dialogue remains largely excellent (read: crass) and you will enjoy the game if you are not looking for something that takes itself (or anything) seriously.

I will say the gameplay is really fun as it was in saints row 3 and the superpowers also added a delightful spin on an otherwise dull version of the previous steelport. The new game takes place in an exact replica city of the previous game, but it is in a virtual world akin to the matrix.. I came into this franchise on SR3, so I feel like i missed a lot of inside humor directed to those who played the first and second games. Also half the people you spend time interacting with were from the previous games, so I highly recommend you dont play this if you havent played other games in the series. I just got SR2 just so I can feel like I can get the part of the story I'm missing / or just apathetic to because I dont have any character development behind it. Also, this game took 1/2 as long to beat as sr3 for me, and it quickly becomes a repetative shooter, but you can jump 1/2 mile high in the air. Last note: once you establish your superpowers you will lose all desire to drive, so the game is has really deviated from its gta like user experience. This game is silly fun with TONS of content. While some of the quests get a little repetitive, if you perform the activities in the open world a lot of them apply to quests automatically, so you're not repeating things just for the sake of the NPC. That's a neat mechanic.  The variation in weapons, super powers, and the controls are =perfect=. It plays very very well with the XBox 360 controller.  I've run into a couple of weird situations where I've glitched through a wall and couldn't find my way back, but both were situations that happened during an event. Just wait for the clock to time out and then everything was fine. It's only happened twice in 20-some hours of play, so not a huge problem.  This game is super fun and I'll end up buying the content DLC because I can't get enough.

Another negative side, for me personally, the lack of choice. In my opinion, developers could add different solutions for key situations in the storyline. In general, the game is quite good ^_^

Saints Row IV is basically Saints Row the Third with superpowers and aliens within a computer in which it's always dark for some reason. That doesn't mean I didn't like it though. These superpowers give nice twists to the different diversions/activities that make Saints Row such a fun game. Although the main story feels more like 'Go do diversion A, B, and C, THEN do something that looks original'. Cars (and planes/helicopters when you upgrade enough) are pretty much useless in this game unless you're doing a diversion that requires them. Volition also stepped up the insanity in this to the point where it's mostly creepy now (Candy Cane Penetrator...really?). Although that's the charm (if you want to call it that) of the Saints Row series.   I give this game a solid buy for Saints Row fans. If you feel skeptical about the superpowers and you have Saints Row the Third, get the Trouble with Clones DLC. Even though it'll only give you that one power for a limited time, it's still a nice, albeit short, introduction to superpowers in Saints Row. On a scale of 0 (totally abhorent) to 5 (Brilliant), I give Saints Row a 4.

Saints Row IV is definitely fun the first time through, but after that, you have to make it fun yourself.  Saints Row IV delivers the ridiculous behavior as usual. It's not as fun as Saints Row 2 (not talking about the thing they call a 'PC version'), but it definitely is fun. Saints Row IV has a adequate storyline that may have you on the edge of your seat, depending if you're easily impressed. Once you beat the storyline and side quests, and DLC's if you buy them, you'll need to download mods to make the game fun. IdolNinja, the community manager for Volition (company that developed all of the Saints Rows), makes great mods, including a mod that can get vehicles that are in the game's files, but not in-game. He has also made a mod to customize aircraft. The list goes on and on.  Now the co-op aspect definitely makes the game fun. If you're picky picky with cheats though, only play with friends. Every person on any Saints Row cheats, so never play public if you want to save.

Stupid...ly fun.  When I first heard of this game, I didn't think I'd like it, but I bought it on sale and I've since changed my mind. A cross of Mass Effect and Grand Theft Auto, with some silly and humorous elements thrown in, this game is perfect if you need to release some stress and your booty call is out of town. Ever dreamed of being a metallic green-skinned hamplanet with cat ears and bondage gear gliding gracefully from building to building between knocking back, and consequently killing, aliens with a tentacle bat? Neither have I, but now I don't have to.  If you want a casual game to play when you get home from a long day of being over-worked by your control-freak boss, this is a good choice. Run over cars and build up your notoriety until powerful enemies show up, then blow them to smithereens with your rocket launcher and dubstep gun, and if that doesn't do it for you, there's mini-games that reward you handsomely for creating as much carnage as possible.

Amazing! Never played Saints Row Anything before, and I don't think I want to. But this game is so fun. I don't know how they crammed so many satires of so many major games in there, and yet built something so unique. Worth it for the minigame commentaries, the romance options, and the classical radio station; and that's just the start.

This game was a delightful romp. It's down right silly most of the time, but that's what give this game it's charm. In Saints Row the Third, this series stopped taking itself seriously and really took off with over-the-top action movie silliness. It just kept going right off the deep end and beyond in this game. I don't think it's quite as good as Saints Row the Third, but if you played the other saints row games and liked them, this game does a good job of tying the series together. It's not so much an epic conclusion, but more of a reunion / farewell party. It looks back the earlier Saints Row games, with lots of cameo appearances from other characters and villans, and even older versions of characters who changed over the course of the Saints Row games. I might have been a little let down paying full price for this game, but it's definately a fun game if you can catch it on sale.   (Spoilers beyond this point)  This game gives you super powers, similar to the Crackdown games. Pretty early in the game, you get the ability to super run and jump over tall buildings, so getting around in any type of vehicle becomes obsolete fairly quickly. I totally missed out on listening to the in game radio stations, because I was never in a vehicle long enough to listen to anything. Some of the super powers actually made it awkward to try and car jack a vehicle. After I got the upgrade to my super-run that sucks objects along with you as you run past, I found trying to run up to a car and jack it, I would usually send it flying. At that point, all you can do is say 'screw it, I'll just fly there,'.   The super powers can be really fun to play with, though. Telekinesis lets you pick up objects and enemies and throw them around. You can hurl fireballs, or jump 10 storeys high and crash down on your enemies with a powerful stomp. There are a few missions you do where your super powers get temporarily disabled, but I didn't find a way to toggle them on and off when you're just playing around freely. That might have been a good option to have, because sometimes all the super powers are unsporting.

I'll be completely honest - I never played Saints Row II or III, and only spent about an hour on Saints Row back in the day. For whatever reason, I just couldn't get into the first one, so I didn't even bother with the second or third installments.  The above said, Saints Row IV is freaking awesome. Perhaps a better word is ridiculous, or hilarious. The game play is akin to the Grand Theft Auto series, with a twist. Instead of being in an urban, open world environment, you find yourself in a simulation - Saints Row IV takes a certain amount of inspiration from the Matrix series. Earth has been destroyed by aliens - enter the evil, yet scholarly English gentleman Zinyak - and it's up to the Saints to destroy the invaders by causing mayhem and completing quests. This is where the game shines - you're able to build up super powers, from jumping multiple stories into the air, to flying, to running at the, well, speed of a bullet, to shooting fireballs, ice chunks, using telekinesis, doing incredible damage via Hulk-like stomps, among others. This is on top of the slew of weapons at your disposal, including a 'Dub Step' gun which causes both enemies and humans within the simulation to break it down.  Pick up this game if, for no other reason, than the comic relief. Go play in traffic and chuckle as the Boss laments what is left of his kidneys - while wearing (should you choose) some of the most absurd clothing options in a game to date. Like I said, hilarious.

This game is one of the most joyful games I've ever played. It somehow celebrates and pokes fun at gaming as a genre, as well as picking at a few big gaming titles (Mass Effect gets the royal treatment) and movies like the Matrix. Despite the game being not much more than a series of loosely-strung-together minigames and missions, it all fits and no one particular part overstays its welcome. The fourth wall is left in ruins by the end, but you won't care because you're having so much fun. This is one of the best gaming buys you can make in 2013.

This is the only game I've ever felt compelled to 100%. My only gripe is that the graphics really haven't advanced at all from Saints Row the Third, but who gives a ♥♥♥♥? Pure, unbrideled awesome. This game, i didn't jump on to right away. So much time wasted, before I played this awesome game!   Picture this; Saints Row 3 and Prototype 2 get drunk at a party and wind up spending the night together in a Volkswagen Vanagon...Nine months later, Saints Row 4. The gameplay is just plain nuts, with superpowers thrown in to the mix along with the obligatory raunchy gang-related shenanigans. If you liked any of the previous installments of Saints Row, you're going to LOVE this game. It's GTA vs. The Matrix, and i'm not sure who is coming out on top. Funny and crazy-good fun, with tight controls and a ton of easter eggs, along with your old favorites, like Prof. Genki.  No matter what sort of crap my day at work has been, this game can cheer me up with a little bit of the ol' Ultra Violence.   Vote Keith David for Vice President!  9 out of 10.

The only place to go from Saints Row 3 was crazierways, and they sure kept up the good work on making everything as nuts as possible without taking itself too seriously at any point. The powers are fun as hell to play around with, but the bad guys' firepower is a bit scaled up as well, and dealing with them can be a little annoying if you're not using all your best weapons sometimes.   Co-op is still great and all, but is way buggier this time around -- my partner in crime has actually gotten his save more or less corrupted a couple of times. Keeping your current and completed quests in sync is kind of a headache, especially in the odd case where it doesn't even want you to do the quest in co-op. But hey, it's still superpowered mayhem with a friend, so you can't hate it too hard.  Car customization is still in, even though most players will probably rarely even use vehicles once they're 15 minutes into the game. They quite improved the color finishes, too. There's also a degree of weapon customization, which is pretty swank if you ask me. Character customization is at least as robust as 3, and you can even just import your SR3 characters if you've set up your online whatnots right, though some of your wardrobe items might no longer exist (I went through the intro mission shirtless, which was actually strangely appropriate).  There's as much Saints Row humor as ever, and also kind of a lot of referential humor this time around, which is all good and well for me. Basically the game is an escalation of the same old, which is... well, pretty much what you want it to be. It still knows exactly what it is, and it's still fun as heck.

As expected, Saints Row IV takes the already sky high crazyness of SR3 and breaks through and far beyond the stratosphere. What starts as a Micheal Bay style middle-eastern military parody which leads to the Saints gaining control of the White House quickly turns into something amazing which takes the setting of The Matrix, the structure of Mass Effect 2 and the superpower abilites of Crackdown / Prototype (complete with Crackdown orbs!).  Combine that with an often witty script and some amazing uses of licensed music and you've got a constantly fun and funny game brimming with 80's nostalgia and numerous jaw-dropping moments.  Just do yourself a favour and play Saints Row the Third first or much of this game won't make any damn sense.

Saints Row IV is, in many ways, Saints Row III with the volume turned up to 11. The game is faster, the powerups are more powerful, and the silly is ridiculous. While the humor in SR3 tickeled the 12-year-old part of my brain, there are many truly funny parts in the sequel. On the downside, much of the environment is just a slight modification of the map from SR3. On the upside, most of the development effort seems to have gone into creating an interesting, entertaining story with many memorable moments. A multitude of small touches on top of fairly well-written dialogue shows the team was really invested in making a great product rather than just cranking out a sequel.  Outside of the story, SR4 is not significantly different from SR3 which is either a good thing or a bad thing depending on how much you enjoyed SR3. The biggest difference in gameplay comes from the new abilities your character has. This gives combat a new dimension but in many cases you'll likely just pick your favorite power and use it over and over again. The downside to the new abilities is that they make cars, planes, and helicopters a pretty uncompelling choice for travel or combat. On the other hand, the ADD part of your brain will appreciate being able to move quickly from mission to mission rather than playing the 'carjack then squeeze between traffic' minigame so prevalant in sandbox games. However, the Saints Row series has combat that seems geared toward the intoxicated gamer, so dwelling on the particulars seems like missing the point. While SR4 is definitely a 'console port,' there are some nice graphic options which help ease the sting of some pretty basic character models and astoundingly low-resolution textures. Another nod to the PC gaming crowd is flawless and instant transition from from gamepad to keyboard + mouse. I personally experienced a sound bug that never got patched and the game crashed a few times, but austosave combined with the ability to save at almost any point kept this from spoiling my fun. While the game is open-ended, the quests drive the action and the action moves quickly. The game is full of fun and ridiculous things to do, but the well-paced storyline will lead you through thirty or forty hours of gameplay before you even pause to wonder how many brain cells have died as a result of playing this very stupid and entertaining game.

While I'm saying you should play this game, don't play it too soon after finishing Saints Row 3. Saints Row IV really just borrows every single asset from SR3 and adds some new gameplay. The super powers were a bit disappointing because you don't even need to drive anymore, and that was one of my favourite parts of the game for SR3. Also, the Warden fights are just too much work to be enjoyable. Maybe I was doing it wrong and I should have called in some help for them, but after a while I just didn't even care too much to get past it.   It's a good game, and true to the Saints Row franchise, but ultimately couldn't hold my interest for longer than what you see on record. And...I wasn't even going for any of the side missions - just the main story line.   Good, but unoriginal.

This is a fun and funny game. Great to play coop. If you liked SR3 you should like this game. Fair warning though, SR4 is essentially a giant dlc for SR3. It is both reassuring and disappointingly familiar. I would have been upset if I paid full price but a sales price will be money well spent.

If you liked Saints Row: The Third, just get it. I promise you'll have fun.  If you didn't like Saints Row: The Third it still might be worth a quick pirate just to try out because the game, while reusing a lot of assets from SR3, plays almost entirely differently. Where SR3 could be considered a GTA-Clone, this title feels more like Infamous or Prototype.  The writing is better than SR3 by a wide margin and made me laugh out loud more than a few times.  Admittidly, it's a little light on content. There's only about 20 hours in the campaign but every hour of that is ridiculously fun.

Definitely an addition to the Saints Row series. Though it felt more like an expansion to Saints Row: The Third which, figuratively, it was. The story unlocks hidden story from SR3 and the assets were all taken from SR3. The only major change was the story.  The game offered me little to no challenge. While I enjoyed the game, being able to unlock unlimited everything, as you could as well in SR3, turned the game into a no-loss situation. What kept people playing this game, in my opinion, was the humor. Everything in the game was turned into a crude joke and people, including myself, enjoyed that. Basically, everything you can apply to Saints Row: The Third can be applied here. Check out my review on that game if you get the chance.   One slight mistake I noticed in the game was the mis-matching challenge medal times. I have a screenshot highlighting it as well. It's very slight but prevalent enough, since you do a lot of challenges in the game, that it bothered me. You couldn't figure out how fast you had to be or how much money you needed to achieve certain medals.  One other issue that really bothered me is that SRIV is basically SR3 with a new story. They could have sold the game as a large expansion to SR3 but decided to sell it as a standalone, I'm guessing to boost sales. All the assets and graphics are the same. It's basically like Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas but without any of the major gameplay additions that New Vegas had and created by the same studio but published by different companies. Yes, there are superpowers now but, that's the only major addition.  All in all, I enjoyed the crude humor and god-like gameplay but, I will probably not be playing it again casually as I have already finished the story and all challenges.

This is an excellent game - recommended. GTA takes itself too seriously, but SR doesn't make the same mistake. All is centered around fun and convenience while still offering plenty of challenges. Pop culture references are all over the place and work very well. Weapons and weapon skins are superb/funny, extra point for the Firefly Captain Mal pistols :). The superpowers are great fun and offer an unparallelled feeling even dozens of hours into the game, however, they offset the game's balance to the point that it's pointless to build your gang or use vehicles to get around, or worry about stores and whatnot. Visually it feels a bit cheap as it is running the same engine and essentially the same city (with tweaks) as in Saints Row 3, which was, to me, a superior experience because of its better story and sense of significance while building my gang and raising to power, as opposed to the one-man-army thing going on in SR4. SR4 is still a very nice twist of the genre, and immensely fun to play. It gets 4.5 stars of 5 (I'd give SR3 the full 5).  I have to mention that achievements are somewhat wrecked as of July 2014. I didn't get most of them unlocked even though I know I did everything required. Also, registering to the community doesn't work in the game, nor on the SR website, so there's that.

SPOILER AHEAD! BE WARNED...  After playing SR3, and having a good time with it, I was eagerly awaiting the next installment in the serie... Boy, was I dissapointed? Sure was!  First of all, this use the very same game engine and map as the third. The vehicles are mostly the same too. What they did change however is the core mechanics of the game: Think 'Matrix' here. You are basically and overpowered 'Neo' that can run faster than a car, jump higher than an helicopter and hit harder than a tank. So, what is the problem you ask?  Well, this renders the vehicles AND guns pretty pointless. In fact, you would do best not to use any vehicles at all since running pretty much is faster and easier. Same goes for weapons. You can hit and throw the opposition with so much power that a rifles becomes unnecessary. After about halfway thru the game, it became clear to me that being OP is not fun! And the game setting, a computer simulation, allow the DEV team to take the easy way out when it comes to what is realistic and what is not. Example: When you throw someone out of a vehicle, it just warp outside it without animation.  If you played the third game, then I would suggest you stick with it or go look somewhere else. If you did not play SR3, pick it before you pick this one. I assure you, 3 is bigger than 4 in this case!

Saint's row IV is less a game and more a wanton mixture of scenes from comedy and action movies, mixed into enough gaming, movie, and other fandom references to make it enjoyable on this merit alone. It doesn't stop there, though; the plot is, while perhaps not deeply dramatic, entertaining and engaging, and the characters are excellent, particularly the main villain.   If you're looking for a deep, engaging game experience where you fight against impossible odds and gradually become master of your environment, this isn't really the game you're looking for. If you're just looking to have fun, sit back and laugh at the madness unleashed by you, your friends, and the world itself, you be hard-pressed to find a better game.

Many have viewed this as the less-serious, distant cousin of the famous franchise GTA and I agree that concepts may the similar but everything else is assuredly not.  With each Saints Row, a bigger, badder version is born. The developers listen to the fans and their concerns and produce a glorious exciting adventure. Plot lines may be ridiculous (no, seriously, you didn't realize that from the previous game?) but it does not diminish the fun and replayability for it.   Secret morals are also learnt, despite the crude yet subtle way it's been put.  Once again, a disclaimer: this game was never made to be serious or a GTA-like game, but it is a game that contains hours and hours of fun and laughs with great voice acting, awesome customization (too much, if you ask me) and super powers. In the immortal words of Avril Lavigne, 'What more can I say?'

Alright just to get this out of the way, this review comes from someone who didnt play 1 or 2. So I entered the franchise at the 3rd installment and loved the satirical nature of the game then saw this which looked like everything 3 had to offer and more so i was sold on the game out the gate but at release i was short on cash then choose GTA at the time but once i crossed over to pc this game happen to be on sale. Enough with the backstory on with the review:  So the game takes place after the events in 3, you and the saints are at a all time high point in your lives and just when when you think nothing is gonna happen yet it does. Earth is invaded by aliens who wish to conquer it and have placed you under a simulation and from there the idea is to fight your way out then find a way to gather the resources needed to retaliate.  Now the game stayed true to the satirical tone from 3 so if you were a fan of that game you'll enjoy this games humor too. Combat wise they stepped it up alot in terms of all the different ways you can fight, Vehicle wise there is couple more cars than there was in 3, environment wise its the same.  Some pros & cons  Pros ~The Powers make getting around town easier and faster especially when being pursued by the authorities ~The Character customization this time around has way more options and features ~The weapons are amazing and cooky ~Co-op actually works (Decent pc port) Cons ~Once you unlock most of your basic powers it makes cars practically useless ~The Wanted system is to aggresive and will not cease pursuit until you kill the boss or use cheats unlike in 3 where you can escape if skilled enough\ ~The mission structure becomes utterly repetative & the game even makes a joke about how of a grind it is ,towards the end of the game ~I hate how some of my favorite location were destroyed (The penthouse HQ in 3) ~And lastly this is way more of a personal gripe but i couldnt stand how it was an endless night cycle through most of the game , half way through there ends up being a reverse but it was a bit annoying   My final verdict is buy it if you liked 3 but only if its on sale since there wasnt that many changes between the games  3.5 out of 5

So, where to start...  This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome! The pros: -Decent character creation and a lot of clothes to make your president super cool. -Decent plot and enjoyable characters on the ship. -It made me laugh very often and the fact that it's not a serious subject game makes it more fun to just ♥♥♥♥ around making disasters.  -A ton of quotes from other games (I think Zinyak is a parody of Brainiac). -Nothing really new in the gameplay but not even boring. -The powers are very cool and they have a lot of incredible powerups! (mostly the super-jump and the fast running). -Romance with everyone on the ship. -Naked young Shaundi in the Benjamin Mother♥♥♥♥ing King rescue quest. the cons: -the powers are cool and all but they are pretty forgettable. They aren't really original and if it wasn't for challenges you could play the game without using the active ones. -I totally hate on foot mayhems. I just find them too difficult and they are the only events that I haven't mastered with gold. -why do even vehicles upgrades exist? With the powers vehicles are completely useless and the upgrades are not even that useful, so just why? -If you put a hat on a guy with long hair he immediatly gets short haired. -I completed the game on 96% and I'm progressing very slowly becouse, I'm my opinion, there are some challenges that are really boring to achieve. -The gang buddies around the town are completely usless and I bought the upgrades just becouse I had money to spend, not becouse they actually do nothing useful. (the number of looks of the buddies tough it's cool. You want a sexy nurse? There's a sexy nurse) -This is not even a con but a question: why do tatoos remain in the real world even if you made them on the simulation? Doesn't really make any sense. -I encountered a few bugs here and there and the game crashed a couple of times but nothing massive.  So, it's not a perfect game but it's very enjoyable and it's a fun game to play for 20/30 hours if you want to do all the optional quests and take it easy doing everything. A tip: don't do by yourself all the challenges in the city like hacking and that stuff becouse you'll lose lines of dialogue in the optional quests and sometime even in the primary quests. Finish them after completing the game. It may sound slower, but trust me, it's worth it. I'll give it a 8/10 I didn't buy the dlc's so this is a review of the game without them.

You're the ♥♥♥♥in' president and you've got super powers!  Well, it's a little more than that.  There are 4 main super powers, Super Jump, Super Sprint, Blast and Buff. They are all fairly generic and their name sums them up, but, for me, its Super Sprint that's the issue. Saints Row is about gangs, guns and cars. However now it's about gangs, guns and super powers. You see? Volition just de-cored Saints Row and messed with the formula and still expect us to feel the same (thats like a Fallout protagonist with a voice... oh, ♥♥♥♥) Yes, there are cars and, yes, they're drivable but no super pimped car will ever beat maxed Super Sprint! Oh and (while we're at it) Super Jump has a glide ability! ♥♥♥♥ THE VTOLS! ♥♥♥♥ EVERYTHING! No more grenades (other minor skills: Telekinesis, Buff, Blast, Stomp) It's a game about gangs, guns and cars, with no need for gangs, guns or cars. The plot is a load of ♥♥♥♥♥, but the dlc is quite good  If you're a Saints fan, you probably won't like it, but if you're new you might! I recommend this gane, but only just!  TL:DR (a quote from me, 5 lines up) It's a game about gangs, guns and cars, with no need for gangs, guns or cars.

I really liked Saints Row 3 and I liked 4 even more, but SR4 is a prime example of a great idea executed poorly. I enjoyed the game as a whole, but not for the story or the missions. The super power system was really well done and it felt like there was a lot you could do by mixing up different elements with powers.  My main gripe with this game is that it just felt lazy and there was a lot to be desired. I went through the game with a feeling of 'Oh they're probably going to add more soon right?' the answer was they really didnt.  They blow their load with content within the first 10 or so hours of the game and then leave you overpowered doing more or less the same thing for the next 20. It's really fun blowing up hordes of enemies, but doing it as a 'loyalty mission' for the 25th time, it starts to lose it's flair. Every mission is a list of side diversions you have to do veiled by a flimsy reason by one of the characters to accomplish 'something' I really do say 'something' because they may as well said just that and it wouldn't have made a difference.  The story missions are about the same thing but with some sort of gimmick thrown in like a stealth section or a side scrolling beat-em-up section, to never be seen again for the rest of the game. It's really disappointing, because I really want to enjoy this game a lot more, but it seems like the developers decided to put minimum effort on an idea that could have been something awesome. The developers added more content, but that's with a grain of salt because they added in about 25% more content on top of the content from Saint's Row: The Third. So the whole thing feels like an expansion rather than a stand alone game, let alone a sequel in the Saint's Row franchise, which normally adds more depth with each new game in the series. Don't get me wrong, I really like SR4 but it fell short in the long run, it seems like one of those games you can pull up and play to kill time with a friend, but other than that I had to play it in bursts to be able to get maximum enjoyment out of it.   TL;DR: I really like SR4, but it seemed lazy and it failed to keep me interested and really fell short after it revealed all of it's content too early in the game. I would recommend picking it up on sale but don't pay full price, and absolutely don't expect anything revolutionary from this game. I'd give it a 7/10 just for the amount of time I played it and enjoyed it.

Well... I absoloutly love this game... best game on steam for me yet. But, its not. And thats for a reason. I bought the game of the century edition on th holiday steam sale. I thought it would be fun with all of the DLC and extras. But... while playing through a mission, I came across a mission that is impossible. Before you say that I am just horrible at the game, read on. On the mission where you driving an airship through the Zin mother ship, you come across the 'final doors' which start to close in on you. Its not that hard! Right? Well, due to a script error (Thanks so much again PC, you really helped me out), the doors close EARLY and it makes it impossible for you to get through them. I cant access all of my DLC, which the only DLC I have gotten to use so far ar maybe 1 or 2 clothes DLC and the extra cheats pack. If you dont believe me, look it up about the final door thing. I really hope that in the future gaming industries will try to put as much effort into PC games than they do for console. Thank you, and wish me luck that one day I MAYBE will be able to get through this.

To sum up Saints Row IV, Totally Batshit Crazy.  This game is incredibly fun, but if you haven't played the previous games a lot of the jokes will not make sense.   For a Rating I'll give it a 9 out of 10.  There are a few annoying and potentially game-breaking gliches, but from what I can tell they only effect lower-end computers as they are primarily loading gliches.  The controls are a little annoying, but since they can be re-mapped as you wish it isn't really that much of a problem.  The Game world is virtually identical to Saints Row III and as such you'll get really bored really quick if you played a lot of SRIII, but it does have some fun and challenging side missions that are worth the effort to complete.  The main story is alright, but I wouldn't call it top-class. It's very obviously a parody-fest of immense proportions, which admittedly is very fun.  The collectables in this game I personally devide into two groups, the first is the fifty or so 'fun' collectables that are interesting and makes the game enjoyable. The second is the thousand or so 'currency' collectables that you need to collect in order to improve an aspect of your character.  Overall, this game is worth the money you're paying for it.

Nothing to complain about whatsoever, really. Game is uber fun and can be picked up and enjoyed in ten minute bites or easily lose ten straight hours to this wacky game world. Tons of content and humour is actually outrageously funny at times. Definitely a surprise because after avoiding the previous games because they looked like an especially juvenlie ripoff of GTA I wasn't expecting a whole lot other than some enjoyable sandbox open world gaming. Definitely worth a buy if you enjoy these types of games like Grand Theft Auto series. It'll surprise you with how competent and thought out the game actually is both in gameplay, content and the often laugh out loud writing.   What appears to be absurd humor is often satire masked as sensationalism. Sound familar? GTA series has always provided an interesting story to go with its sandbox gaming. The game gets off to a rollicking start. You even have Aerosmith's 'I Don't Want To Miss A Thing' as your theme tune while thwarting a nuclear missle launch that you have just leapt upon and commence dismantling in-flight.   The designers consistently show time and time again that Rockstar North might enjoy rubbing your nose in s*** and making you like it. But Deep Silver are all about a drug trip gone delightfully and derisively wrong. Wonderfully, wonderfully wrong. Managing to have a solid command of my funny bone with, at times, concise and cutting humor that actually had me thinking between the slew of purile potty mouthing.

Saints Row IV: If GTA was on Acid and probably a little bit drunk  Visuals -SR4 holds true to the style of the previous Saints Row games -Not extremely realistic like most games are leaning towards but fits the game perfectly -Funny and at times cartoony visuals (but it works trust me)  Audio -Some of the funniest dialogue I have ever heard in a game -loads of cursing, profanity, and pretty much some of the most random things ever heard in a game -Good soundtrack featuring some real life music  Gameplay -Loads of fun -Hilarious storyline -Funny characters -Lots of weapons/upgrades -You get superpowers (yea, superpowers) -You are a badA** president (a good one? probably not) -fun minigames/ side missions -loads and loads of violence (yum, violence)  Extra -You get to hit people with a huge Tentacle sword called The Violator...c'mon what else do you want -Energy swords. -Aliens -Funny character editor -Fun DLC  Overall: This game is hilarious and I had a ton of fun playing it. The dialogue is some of the funniest things i have heard in a video game and at times wondered if they were even allowed to say some of the stuff. Funny characters even funnier storyline. Great gameplay with loads of violence and shooting. Think GTA on drugs. 8/10

I'll be honest; I walked into SR:IV not knowing a single thing about the things that happened in prior games, and quite frankly, this has turned out to be an amazing title that has decent re-playability. One major point I have to make about this game is the customization: I don't know if this was just me, but making a customizable main character was what made the game for me. This is mainly because as the story progressed, I continuously noticed that my own character grew with the other characters, and in turn, so did I. If I didn't have the customized character I did when I played this game for the first time, it would have been a boring and plain game. Furthermore, the well orchestrated humour of this title made me laugh more than once and there are moments that I will never forget about this game (e.g the hilarious sing-a-long). Lastly, I would also recommend playing Saints Row: The Third BEFORE Saints Row: IV, as it gives you a back-story on what happened before this title, has a lot of humour just like its follow-up and to be fair SR:TT is a fantastic game in its own right too.

I really couldn’t decide to vote up or now on this, eventually I decided that, if your new to the series, then the down vote goes to you guys I would really recommended trying Saints Row the Third over this game! That game is awesome! If your are a fan of 3, like I was then, like me your going to get this game anyway, so for you guys its a up vote, just read on too be prepared for the disappointments of this game. This game was supposed to be DLC and you can tell, it's basically SR3 except when that mission when you where all drugged up and out of your mind, so you super speed (and lets be honest, was awesome)....well someone thought, lets make an entire DLC of that, then someone thought, no lets make it a full priced game.  So remember that you can mod your cars, well you can still do that, great right, no pointless you just run everywhere instead but ok, it’s nice that they still give you that option, right? Yeah, nowt to do with the fact that its just SR3 game, with your running and jumping code tweaked so you seem super. Well how about the story, well for the DLC I'm assuming, that it would of gone straight to the alien invasion but this is a new game, so we gotta give them abit more than that, so....erm.... lets see, they where famous celebs in the 3rd one....so lets have them running the whole country now! So you do an opening mission, which is nowhere near as good as the opening mission on the SR3 and then...bang! You’re the Prez! Just like that! Would have been so much better, actually giving you a story on how you become the President. Just think of it.... political missions, taking out the competition, planting 'interesting' items in your rivals homes, call in your friends to give you political backing, you know who I’m thinking of, some more Burt Reynolds! Etc etc etc. And then, ok so we're the Prez now, so some great missions involving blowing up other countries? No you’re like the Prez for 5 secs and then aliens attack and you’re back too doing exactly the same as SR3 because it was supposed to be just an add-on for SR3! After like 2 hours, I just couldn’t play anymore! But saying that, when my friend got the game, we started up a co-op game and it’s great, it’s all the fun of playing SR3 again! The story? Who cares?! We too busy talking to each other over the cut-scenes to care! And then with the Super Powers, its race to each new mission, super speeding down the streets, blasting things as we go! I give this a 'Thumbs Down' because in SR3, I loved it! I enjoyed playing it solo, taking my time, enjoying the story, hell I would go change outfits depending on what the mission was! This is just a frenzy co-op game, not worth full price! But sale price, especially with the extra content to give it abit more padding, its certainly an enjoyable time, if not quite the fitting end to the franchise (and by franchise I don't mean any spin off games) it should have been.

I cannot speak for all fans of the Saints Row franchise when I say that I was incredibly pleased by this title. This was my first exposure to the brand and I must say that it was quite pleasing. There is an argument that this installment is not as good of a game as its predecessors; with this I can agree. I found Saints Row 2 and Saints Row: The Third to be more fun games, as well as more intuitive games, but in a different way than this piece. I really appreciated the satire implemented into this game that was directed both at modern standstills, as well as political matters pertaining to the United States. I was able to enjoy it so much, probably as a result of this game setting my expectations for the series, which I don't mind. I was able to greatly enjoy the two previous installments as well as some DLC that adds story based content to the game, as well as content placed sheerly for the enjoyment of the player. The game had some problems mechanically, but given the complications of my hardware, it is most likely a personal issue that most players would not experience. This game earned a 9/10 from the Fox.

10-20 hours of solid content on offer.   The gameplay loops are varied , the game uses over 20 systems. Some of it is quite surprising and unexpected, but only a few hours of truly original content. You have experienced all of the gameplay on offer here before, in numerous games.   The presentation of the game is cheapish ,you've seen these graphical and physics engines and many of the art assets before, but it's directed very well. Songs and licenses are used very strategically in service of the 'Family-guy' style of referential random humor.   The story is about the antics of an impractically racially diverse urban Americana gang. It's just a vehicle for the jokes. It doesn't aspire to be an emotional drama or present it's lore seriously (although there are audio logs to find if you really are curious about Saint's Row lore).   Play this to sample and taste the gameplay systems and view the authored content. Some of the scenes are entertaining, and the game throws different systems at you constantly.   Just make sure you make full use of these various systems. The game's 'authored' content is only 5 hours or so.

The best way to summarize what this game is like is by using the shark jumping trope to describe the series and compare it that way. Saints Row pretty much played it straight. Pros: ------  + Wide clothing selection  + Biggest gun selection i've seen in a game like this   + Insane graphics that are yet manageble on decent computers  + Very nice audio (The script is very funny especially Zinyak)  + GAT!!!!!  + Plenty of quests each with there own awesome reward  + Plenty of DLC Quests and items that were all around great  + Vehicles (Especially air types) are awesome   + Was able to ♥♥♥♥ off Australia to ban this game  Cons: -------  - Recycled map from SR3  - A little bit repeatitive missions  - Super Powers ( I will explain this later)  - Vehicles are useless ( Again, I will explain later)  - A.I Is not the brightest at times  - Certain weapons are OP (Black Hole Gun for example)  - Water textures are a little glitchy and might be missing a texture   Lets Talk: ---------- What ruined the game: Like I had said in my cons, the Super Powers and vehicles are just dumb. Super Powers (Dont get me wrong... Are INSANLEY fun...) but they are just way to over powered.... They completely get rid of the old like feeling of Saints Row where you will never need to drive around because you have Super Sprint that can take you there in half the time. Driving was one of SR biggest acomplishments but is now ruined because of  Super Sprint. Also, Super Powers are very OP in combat. I personally think if SR 4 had made the Super Powers avalible on certain missions  and would be all unlocked once the game is beat.  The Map ---------- Now the map is very fun and pretty itself, but that still is no excuss to the developers to not make a new map and  just recycle the old map. I will admit there are some new additions but not all that much.  Conclusion: SR4 Is a very fun game, and with 30.7 hours I have still not completed it because of the amount of missions and fun there is to do. I have recommened this game to many friends of mine and all have the same opinion.... Its amazing... I will admit I did like SR3 A bit better then this but my overall score for this game out of 100 is....  89/100 (For lack of new map and Super Powers)  Cheers! (Please rate the review!)

UPDATE 2016: My first review was done shortly after the game was released. Now that all of the dust has settled and the game has had numerous updates and DLCs and a GOTY style package with everything, I'd say it is absolutely worth the current retail price of $19.99 USD. I still think there were some valid points in my original review, so I'm going to leave it below. However, I've changed my recommendation from a No to a Yes.  BELOW IS MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:  Is this a fun game? Yes. Is this a game that is worth paying retail for? No. This game was originally supposed to be just an expansion DLC for Saint's Row: The Third. Then someone said, 'With all the work we are putting in, we should charge three times as much.' And Saint's Row IV was born. Don't get me wrong....the game is quite enjoyable and has a fair amount of content to keep you busy for a while. But it is very clear this game was not meant to be a stand-alone product, and that shows in the details (polish, bugs, etc). Then we get to the DLC....the real issue here. This company has a history of nickel & diming their customers to death with tons of small DLC packs. Pay 3 dollars for new outfits. Pay 2 dollars for a new skin for your guns. Pay 7 bucks for a new set of generic missions that are no different than the already-included missions. Or my personal favorite...pay 10 bucks for a 'Season Pass' that, in any other game, would entitle you to ALL the DLC that will be released for the game. Except in this game, it doesn't do that. The name is completely misleading, and entitles you to 2 of the larger DLC packs, one of which has yet to be released. You STILL get nickel & dimed for everything else. Sure, you'll discover this if you read the fine print. But it's this spirit of 'Let's milk our customers' that really leaves a bad taste in your mouth when playing games by this company. It isn't anything new, but keep in mind that they are leaving elements of this game out with the intention of getting MORE money from you at a later date. I, for one, will not be purchasing games from this company again. Consumers don't need to encourage this type of parasitic behavior.

I bought this game thinking that it was just a goofier, more over-the-top GTA clone. I was wrong. But where this game shines is it's oddities, WTF moments, Superpowers, and crude (adult) humor. As a geek with a dirty mind and and a weird sense of humor, I think this game is awesome. Admittedly, it took me a few weeks to get into it. I bought it and the DLC on sale for 6.79 or something. Played for about an hour, got frustrated, and quit. A friend told me to continue, to give it a chance, so I did. And I'm glad I did. Where else will you get the chance to force furries into giant cages with telekinesis? Or kill with a device you shove up people's @$$ and launch them into orbit? NOWHERE.

I would recommend this game only to those who are seeking more silly factors in a game than a serious game with grounded plot.   I first played this game on the PS3 and just recently bought it for my laptop because I enjoyed it so much--totally not because I wanted to mod the game, hahaha--so how i would judge the game, it's very fun to play! Tons of minigames andfun gameplay, nothing more satsifying than killing aliens with a giant purple ♥♥♥♥♥ bat! Haha!  Story 4/10: Okay, okay, despite all the fun I had with this game, the plot is very generic and simple. An antagonist from another world to conquer Earth and trap thousands of people inside a simulated reality, which is pretty much a reference to 'The Matrix', a fantastic movie by the way, Anyways, the missions are mostly introducing you to the minigames and the story is very weak as a result, and doesn't have any real replay value.  Gameplay 7/10: This game is an open world environment similar to GTA--a lot of people compared this game to GTA when Saints Row 1 and 2 came out, so I'm sticking with it--with guns, laser beams, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥! Wait.. that's not right. Moving right along, yes, there are super powers in the game, another reference to 'The Matrix', which you level up by collecting 'Data Clusters' around the city of Steelport, which adds some incentive to explore the simulated city of Steelport, which I enjoyed.. despite being forced to go back to there from Saints Row the Third. So in short, if you like 'The Matrix' and love silly gameplay and super powers, then I recommend this game just for this.  Enjoyment 9/10: I enjoyed the game very much, which, yes, most of this review is a mix of my PC experience and console experience, I've had enough PC experience--somewhat--to give a review on this game. Although it was fun to do, there is ONE section of the game which was almost impossible! I had to lower my resolutiion just to get through it! It's when you escape a ship.. you'll know the one.

A seriously entertaining game with still decent graphics and outrageous superpowers that you get to abuse in every way that you ever wanted to after trying Freedom Force or City of Heroes back in the day. It's all done expertly here, and never gets boring. Combat and movement is enjoyable with or without a controller.  You can customize stuff to your heart's delight. The comedy elements and lovable characters make the world come alive. If you want less sci-fi and aliens, go for SR3, though. Personally, I love both games. Gat Out of Hell is also worth it if you've played this game, but I think it has less replay value. This is the best Saints Row game.

It crashed for me once but of course it's a really fun game and experience and a great addition to the Saints Row collection, beware that it will not work on some PCs/Laptops though and even if it does it can lag a lot even on lower res and sometimes makes the game unplayable past certain missions, however saying that, if you have a system that can play it then I'd suggest going for it because damn is it fun, especially with the added powers including Telekinesis and Ice Blast, Hacking is also quite fun and a good way to kill time, I especially love some of the abilities and the side missions are very fun, I sometimes find them more fun than the main game but that just makes it an overall fun game and doesn't make it a tedious chore if you want to 100% the game, it's probably one of the only games I have 100% completed.
